  1. Great tool once you get the hang of it!
  2. Awesome product!! My tip... Use a warm/hot wash cloth on your face first for a couple min. This will help a lot and it's not as painful to use the spring. I think it works great I've had mine for 2 years now. & I just bought my mom one!
  3. This works really, really well. It hurts a tad, but nothing I can't take. The only con is that I got sort of obsessive with it. I want to use it every day to get every single darn hair off my face, which is obviously unnecessary.
  4. Ordered 3rd one ...1 lost, 1 for gift and 1 for myself again..it's little make the skin dry and time consuming
  5. I really like this device, however, the description of how to use it is way off. I tried it like the instructions say and nothing. Then I tried it how it made sense to me and it works great. I kept it almost straight, and rolled it up and down, on my face and arms, and it worked great. I have recommended it to several friends. The 4 stars instead of 5 is because of bad instructions.
  6. Hurts but it works, I have been waxed, plucked, and spent several hundred on the no-no. All the products worked well but this spring is quick easy and the results last a long time. I am happy with the purchase I just wish I knew about it years ago!
  7. I bought a second one to be sure I always have one! I am still using the original one I bought a few years ago and I love it. It is amazing how much &#34;fur&#34; we have on our faces and this R.E.M. Spring is better than wax, threading or hair remover (ouch) I've ever tried or used.
  8. I was really surprised that the R.E.M. Spring Facial Hair Remover worked as well as it did. It is a little painful but you get it over with a few quick pulls rather than the bunch of little pulls you get with tweezers. I have dark, coarse hair and it gets most of those. I still do a little finishing with tweezers.
  9. A spring such as this is used for facial hair removal. It's supposed to be painless, but it isn't. It does remove some hairs, but not all. Maybe tweezers are the answer after all.
  10. I found this very easy to use. It works very well, but it does hurt! easy to use while watching tv .Could also probably double as a weapon.
  11. A second one for my suitcase to have always at the ready! Yes, it takes practice to get the hang of it. Spin and twist the ends in opposite directions; roll it all over, in every direction. Use often and it does a great job. So much better than the electric epilator I bought. Cleaner and more convenient than waxing.
  12. It does what the description said it will do. I would suggest watching the YouTube video for best directions.
  13. This product really works great. It only took me a few minutes to get it down pat and now works like a charm. The only downside is it was slightly painful at first till I learned to firm my lip before pulling out my lip hair. I suggest sort of using your facial muscles to stiffen your lip in the place you are going to be using it on. I found it to be much less painful and actually kind of like doing it now. If you are someone like me who has been dealing with the problem of unpleasant facial hair I would highly recommend getting yourself one. Well worth the asking price in my opinion.
  14. I've used the spring for about a month or so now, and wanted to set the record straight since my first review. It's a good touch-up product, and works okay (although painful) on certain type of hair. It has done well removing fine hairs from the upper lip and slowed their regrowth there, BUT unfortunately not so well on chin hairs. After one month of use I've noticed the chin hairs have slowed in fully growing, but have turned more like stubble, and covering a larger area... not good! I'm discontinuing use of the spring as the primary way for hair removal and going back to waxing. It's still useful for on- the go touch ups when waxing is not convenient.
  15. Did not seem at all painful to me. At age 70, my facial hair was very aging. Face is now fuzz-free. Hopefully I can throw away the cream I've been using for years and touchups will be easier.
  16. The spring seems to only grab fine hairs, completely missing the darker, thicker hairs on my chin that I purchased this to address. It's also painful and time consuming. Not worth it.
  17. I used this while sitting on the coach. The first minute I didn't feel anything and realized I wasn't bending it enough. Once I figured it out, it pulled a little--only a bit painful on the upper lip.<br /><br />Very quick, very easy, inexpensive and no chemicals to burn the skin. LOVE IT!
  18. Wow...just wow... This one is perfect... No need to use those wax or those harsh hair removed, this one is perfect... It might hurt a little but its worth the hurt ...
  19. Seems to work very well and frankly any good hair removal has some pain involved. I find if I use it in just a small area at a time, then take a break, that I can deal with the pain. I am very fair skinned but absolutely hate how furry my face has gotten with age. No coarse hair grows back just like with waxing or plucking which is a plus.
  20. Overall, I like the product but honestly, with the coarser facial hair I have, I think I'm better off with a standard tweezer. I got this to get rid of the very fine hairs that are noticeable up close on my face but I hate how time-consuming using this hair remover can be because it misses some of the hairs and I have to spend time constantly try to get rid of it by twisting it in different directions. Sometimes, I have to have a half an hour session just getting rid of those hairs. And the fact that they grow back so quickly? So annoying. Being able to grow hair fast is a blessing but also a curse in disguise. I was hoping I'd only have to use this about once every two weeks but I find that in order to be perfectly hairless, I have to probably use it every 3 or 4 days. Then there's the fact that it hurts like a bitch in my more sensitive areas. Anyway, it's a good product so I shouldn't complain too much but honestly, I wouldn't buy it again if I were to lose it or something.
  21. I read the reviews about this on Amazon. The reviewers are correct in that there is a little bit of a learning curve. In fact, the first time I used it I was a little overzealous, pressed too hard and gave myself some temporary bumps. But the hint about holding the spring further up from the handles saved the day. And the best part, no 5 o'clock stubble. (I can't believe I'm saying this!) Keeping up with it daily to hit the strays is key. Spend the $20 if you've reached this stage in your life.
  22. I'm a very fair-skinned brunette who comes from a very hairy family. I've tried all sorts of ways to deal with my moustache, from ignoring it (until my new niece pointedly asked why her new aunt had a moustache), to depilatories (which led to chemical burns and owieness), to waxing (which left me red for hours), to threading (which hurts like a sonuvagun but doesn't leave me red). This is comparable to threading except that I can do it myself. It yanks the hairs out nicely, hurts like a sonuvagun for few seconds, but then I'm left with nice hairless skin. Woot!
  23. I just got it today and used it right away. It works really well. I wish I knew this product before.
  24. I have had this product for about six weeks and I LOVE it. I have quite a lot of coarse chin hair. It has always embarrassed me. I've tried tweezing, waxing, trimming- all with less than satisfactory and usually painful results. The REM spring is very easy to use and does not hurt. I get the best results if I use it right after washing my face in hot water before using any moisturizer. I've also learned that it helps to try rolling the spring in different directions over the same area. It only takes seconds to use and there is literally no mess. This is the BEST beauty product I have ever bought. I highly recommend it!
  25. This was really effective for the first few times I used it. It hurts really bad at first, but you'll get use to it. The reason this has three stars is because the hairs that are being pulled are getting stuck in the middle, which is hard to remove inside the coil. Not only that, but the handle became a little loose. Otherwise, this is a great alternative to remove facial hair. Fast and Effective.
  26. I found that this didn't really work that well. When it did grab a hair or two, it hurt like crazy. Not worth the trouble to return it, but it went in the trash.
  27. With all the phenomenal reviews on this product, I expected much more. After using several times, I find it okay, at best. What does bother me is that it is time consuming to use, and it doesn't even get all the hairs...or even close. You have to run over each area many times in several different directions, and even then, I wouldn't call the job it does \\"satisfactory.\\" Also, as I had read in at least one other review, it does appear to \\"break\\" some hairs rather than pull them. Therefore, I still end up tweezing in addition to using this. :(

It's super easy to use, there is no learning curve - just put the spring on there and roll. I've found you don't have to bend it for it to work, just play around with and see what works best for you.

  40. After reading other reviews, I made sure to wash my face both before and after use. I also used an astringent and my normal moisturizer when I was done. This product still made be break out in the worst acne I've ever had...maybe it just doesn't work for everyone. If you still want to try it, I'd recommend doing it when your life is pretty low key (i.e. not right before a job interview, reunion, photo session). That way, you can give your face time heal.
  41. I am so happy I took a chance and bought this item. It is much easier to use, much less painful, and much more effective than I expected - and gets easier very quickly. My skin is very soft and smooth. It is actually a little addictive. Different degrees of bending do the job. As instructed, you have to be very careful around the eyebrows, but I found that I can shape the spring over my brow and work up and away. I have been looking for the right product for years. My only concerns are how long it will last and whether they might stop making it - I ordered a second one immediately and am actually thinking of buying a few more spares.
  42. I am a light skinned, brunette. I've had a mustache since I was 8 years old.. so needless to say my battle against my facial hair started early. I have literally tried it all. Depilatory creams, bleaches, microwave waxes, pre- waxed strips. I even spent about $70 at Sallys buying a wax warmer and all the accessories to use with it (which I am still grateful for..for the eyebrows!) and then when that became to cumbersome to keep up with every other day, I invested in an epilator. I have tried it all, with varying results.. but this tool has change everything!! You do not have to be in front of a mirror, or near an outlet! I pick it up while I'm watching TV and go over my trouble areas.. or right before I wash my face at night. I use it everyday and I no longer have those inbetween waxing days where I feel less confident, my face is always hair free and smooth now. Now, I do have fast regrowth so someone less hairy might not have to use it ever day, but if you have to, this is the tool to do it. The irritation is minimal, I only experience redness for 15-30 minutes, whereas with waxing, 6 hours later my face would still be red. There is a little bit of a learning curve, I just searched on youtube for tutorials or videos of people using it. You just have to turn the ends away from each other while moving the upside down \\"U\\" against the grain of the hair growth. Also play with the angles and the width of the U for different parts of your face. The more you use it, the more you'll get it! For $[...] I have regained a lot of confidence in my appearance, buy it.. you will not regret it.
  43. this product does work. the pain isn't that bad. i did experience some breaking out. my only problem is getting around the curve of my jaw and the fact that it doesn't go everywhere on your face (between brows e.g.) for me, i would have to use this every couple days to stay hair-free, which i haven't done yet because i am leery of my skin breaking out.
  44. It is great and really remove hair by the roots without breaking them out , but you have to be accustomed to using it correctly to get the best result. I used to go to salon to remove my upper lip hair but after I've got one of spring sprong , i do my upper lip by myself. It a Little bit hurts but it saves my time and money ,and enables me to enjoy the best result ever .
  45. I am generally very skeptical of such products but this one actually works. I opened it and without much trouble figured out how to make it work. In 10 mins I had good hairless upper lip. It is best for upper lip, can work on chin and cheeks too. But it wont work on eye brow area. Also, it needs a blowing through every now and then otherwise it does not work to it full potential. And if you have oily skin, you need to use a tissue to clean the skin first. I am happy that I can do it anywhere even without the need of a mirror.
  46. Works pretty well. You have to play around with it to figure out what works best. The only downside is that it doesn't grab short hairs, and I can't figure out how to clean out the inside of the coil.
  47. Works well, once you get the hang of it! Beats the one by one method of hair removal using tweezers!
  48. I recently starting becoming self-conscious of the small brown hairs mixed in with the blond one on my upper lip (I just turned 30- ugh!). For several years all I ever did was cut them close to the skin with manicure scissors. This worked temporarily, but it certainly wasn't a long term solution. My first step to a clean upper lip was to try an at home waxing strip. That worked as well, but my lip was red for hours. I decided to purchase the Spring, because the reviews were great. The first time I used the product I was shocked at the amount of pain involved. It really does hurt! If your skin is very sensitive to pain you might want to consider going to a professional (obviously you will still be in pain, but you aren't inflicting it upon yourself), or bleaching might be your best bet. Well, I let the hairs grow back a little, and I tried this product again. The second time around the pain seems to have subsided a bit. I suppose I knew what to expect, so the pain was more tolerable. I would recommend this product to anyone that does not want to spend the money at a salon, and to someone that can handle the small bits of pain. The money spent is well worth it!
  49. Make no mistake, there are many, many nerve endings on your upper lip, using this device stings- BUT IT WORKS. And since the hairs grow back at different rates, the first time will be the worst. I like the fact that it tends to grab the longer, coarser hairs, aka the hair you really want to be gone, and doesn't do a \\"clearcut\\" like shaving or waxing. I've always had a lot of hair everywhere and having absolutely no hair on my face would just be weird. If I kept at it I could get rid of it all, so it's even customizable.
  50. This is an amazing product and works as described by other Amazon reviewers. I also learned from other reviews that the hair removal might be painful but this was only in learning how to use the tool in my case. I would not hesitate to recommend this item. It does remove the hair!
  51. Works like a charm! Didn't get a few short hairs but got everything else... No more tweezing for me, thank God!!
  52. This thing does exactly what it is supposed to do. I pulls out your fine hairs and it is easy to use. it's a solid little tool for removing that nasty little mustache that women shouldn't have. I like it so much I bought a second one for my friend.
  53. Easy to use and it really works! I still go to the salon occasionally for brow shaping, but this is a great tool for general upkeep.
  54. The REM is the best hair removal tool ever! I have tried so many things over the years- waxing, hair removal creams, electrolosis, lazer hair removal- but after a time, I realised that the process was either time consuming, expensive, or left the surface area uneven. I read the reviews about this, but basically bought it as it said it was on Oprah- and we all trust the big O. When it arrived, I remember reading that some people had problems with how to use it- so I took my time to use it in different ways, trying to find the way that works best for me. What works best for me- is to actually roll it almost straight- with my fingers on the springy part- I just start at one end and roll it to the other in the opposite direction that the hairs are growing. You can actually see the hairs being picked out by their roots- so many at once- it's awesome. I will never use anything else again. This is so cheap, so easy and so effective. Buy with confidence.
  55. I've been taking myself to the waxers to remove irksome facial hair for more than a decade now, but I'll never go again. This device works remarkably well to remove even tiny hairs on the chin, cheek and upper lip. The discomfort involved is negligible and the product more than paid for itself during the first week I used it. If I use it for half a minute or so every day, my face remains perpetually mustache-free. Whoever invented this thing deserves to be rich. Learning the knack of using the Spring Sprong is pretty easy, but if you want some tips just search YouTube to see the device in action. (I love this thing, but not enough to create a demonstration video! It fascinates me that some people care enough to go to such trouble.) I don't write many reviews, but the Spring Sprong deserves a plug.
  56. This is a fantastic product; once you get the hang of it, it is faster and more efficient than a tweezers. There is occasionally a hair or two left for my now neglected tweezers to take care of, but I don't mind. If you're sick of tweezing your chin or upper lip, pony up the cash, you'll be glad you did.

  61. I've been using the R.E.M. Spring for about a month now. I have a lot of visible blonde facial hair that I have always been self conscious about. In the past, I've regularly gotten it waxed or threaded. However, money is tight now so I decided to look for a cheap product I could use at home. I have very sensitive skin so I was wary of trying to wax it myself or using a depilatory cream.<br /><br />When I found the R.E.M. Spring, it seemed like it was worth a shot. As other reviews have said, it takes a little figuring out and the first use or two can be pretty painful. However, once you figure it out and get over the \\"first-use\\" pain, it really seems to do the trick.<br /><br />I like that I can see the hairs and their roots on the Spring, that it's small and lightweight, and that I can use it whenever I need to for a quick touch up. I generally use it 2-3 times a week.<br /><br />My only complaint is that I find it doesn't rip the hairs out from the root on my chin like it does elsewhere on my face. I'm hoping that with more use I can figure out an angle to hold it at so it doesn't just break the hairs there. Other than that, I am very happy with the product.
  62. At first I was scared to use this because I heard it hurts a lot at first. But then I built up my courage and used it and it doesn't hurt at all! It works very well too! I recommend this product because it works well and it's easy!
  63. First of all, the instructions for this say that you'll feel a slight tingling sensation. This is a lie. You will feel each individual hair being ripped from your flesh, not unlike some form of medieval torture. That said, though, the spring does work.<br /><br />I'd say that the pain is about on the level of tweezing (which I find more painful than waxing) and it's not unbearable, but if you're going to be using this thing on sensitive facial areas or for any prolonged amount of time you're going to feel it and it won't be pleasant.<br /><br />The hair removal itself isn't particularly consistent, but if you stick with it you will get results. It's pretty easy to use. You just do as the instructions say--bend it into an inverted u, place it against your skin where the hair is, and twist the handles (in the same direction). All it does is literally catch the hairs between the wires of the spring, and as you twist back and forth the hairs are pulled out.<br /><br />Overall I'd give it a solid \\"OK\\" because it does what it says it will, but it's not any kind of miracle product.
  64. I had reservations about this product, but figured I'd give it a try. I am so happy I did. It REALLY does the job. There is no learning curve to it...Just bend it and roll over the places you want hair to be removed. It was a bit uncomfortable the first time I did it because I didn't think it would take as many hairs all at once as it did. However, my best advice to those using this is to think of it like pulling off a band aid...do it fast!! I found that if I rolled the spring quickly over the area, it was far less painful than doing it slowly. And, it seems to work much more effectively at removing hairs. Once you get the majority of the hair removed, just follow up every couple of days for maintenance and there is virtually no pain involved. I have thrown away all my hair remover creams since purchasing this. I have ever found a product to work as effectively as this and will never use anything else! I highly recommend this tool to EVERYONE who wants smooth skin!
  65. The product arrived on time. I read the reviews from other people who had purchased it and had no trouble using it to remove facial hair.   76. I received this a few days ago and was looking forward to using it. As a fair skinned brunette I get some dark hair on my upper lip and also a few dark hairs on the upper side of my neck. The last thing I used that worked was a cream kit but for two days after my upper lip was so swollen and red from the chemicals I could barely talk. I would have to sleep with Neosporin on my upper lip after using the cream since it was so harsh. I read the reviews for this `spring' and figured I would give it a try.<br /><br />Upon receiving it I was doubtful. It comes in a box with poorly explained instructions. It does come with a nice soft case to keep the spring in which was a plus. I read the instructions and it stated to hold the spring in an upside down `U' shape and push in and outward. I took the spring to a mirror and for 30 minutes nothing happened. I was ready to chalk this up to another failed device. I then watched the video for the device and it more or less is trying to sell it to you and not show you how to use it. I then went to the most popular video website and typed in the item and found one where a woman demonstrated using it. Right away I realized that when you hold it upside down you need to twist the ends left and right continuously in order for it to work. It did not state this in the instructions. Back to the mirror I went and sure enough with me twisting the ends constantly I felt it `grab' the hairs and slowly removing them. I will not say it was painless but then again your upper lip area is a very sensitive area. I was able to remove all the hairs and I did not have any redness after. It hurt during the process but no more pain afterwards. I also used it on the side of my upper neck and it removed those hairs as well. I did put some oil free moisturizer on my upper lip after to prevent any dryness.<br /><br />When I was done I tapped the device hard to remove any loose hair and put it in the soft case it came with. Please note you cannot clean the device with water since it will rust. It recommends being cleaned with high pressured air. I will keep cleaning it the way I have been and hope it stays clean. Also remember to not share this with anyone, not even a family member. Not being able to disinfect it completely you don't want to risk the possible infection to another person.<br /><br />I must say when I first tried this I thought it was a waste and pure junk but now that I know how to use it I am so thankful for it.   104. I have ordered this product for gifts to family and friends. I have used it and it works great. I can use it while I am watching TV, because you don't need a mirror; just touch the area until it feels soft.
  105. The product description mentions nowhere that this item cannot be used on eyebrows. It says so in the instructions in the package. The U-bend is wide enough to not fit between the brow or under it, risk of catching eyelashes. As for upper lip - it worked, but only cut the hair short instead of pulling them out so I was left with very tiny hair that couldn't be tweezed or waxed and had to be bleached. I got it with free shipping with Prime, but the return shipping will be $6, so not worth returning.
  106. It is ok for hair removal on the upper lip, but I just can't get it to work on my cheeks or chin at all, so I suppose for light touch ups on the upper lip in between waxing it works, but I can't rely on this for my only method of hair removal. It stings a bit, but I don't think it is too painful to deal with.
  107. Surprisingly easy to use, much easier than some of the other reviews led me to expect. Very effective, and relatively painless. Sure, there's some stinging but nothing to make your eyes water or anything. Less than 2 minutes and I was done. Fantastic invention.
  108. If you tweeze, wax or use a shaving facial groomer, this is way better. It does smart the first few times, but so does tweezing or waxing. VERY fast, little to no irritation, and it's totally portable. No more worries about bright sunshine, close-up encounters. Sure, it's just like a minature slinky with handles, and probably costs $0.01 to manufacture, but compared to the cost of other hair removal systems and the sheer ingenuity and speed of the product, it's worth the $13.00 any day!!
  109. So I have to admit that I couldn't figure out how to make this thing work until I went on the web and found a few video's with demo's on them. Once I watched and practiced, I had no problem using this product. If you've ever had your face \\"threaded\\" before, then you'll recognize the discomfort. This little tool is really handy! I'm a Latina and have plenty of unwanted hair on my face!! This cool spring really does a great job getting rid of all the fuzzy, fine hair all over your face. For thicker hairs, it's a hit or miss...but that's what tweezers are for. I use mine every few days so that the hairs are still short and it hurts less the more often you use it. Be careful near your eyes and eyebrows, you cam easily snag hairs you didn't intend to remove...but otherwise...go nuts! The tighter you can make the skin in the area you're working on, the better the results. I love being hair free, my skin looks so much nicer without the fuzz! :) Be sure to use a mild toner afterward and moisturize! They help the redness fade quickly...
  110. I was skeptical. I have been fighting the stash for a few years... I don't want to talk about it.<br />This works amazing!   117. I've got dark hair on my upper lip (that I usually bleach)and those annoying \\"goat hairs\\" on my chin. Well, the older I get, the harder it is to tweeze those little devils since I can't hardly see them any more, dagnabit. This REM spring yanks them out pretty well. I am finding it easier to use than I expected. Pulling the hairs above my lip was quite easy, in fact, it took very little time to make a noticeable difference. It takes more persistence to get the ones under my chin. I expect this is due to the shape of my face, since the spring seems to work better on a more convex surface and it's easier to pooch out your lip than your neck. (For me, anyway!) I certainly wouldn't call this a painless procedure (how could ripping hair out be painless?) but it's not bad, especially if you don't go crazy and try to get every last hair right away. Also, I have to admit that I love the fact that this little gizmo is silent, unlike the epilator I considered buying. Because if I had to deal with my kids coming in the bathroom to see \\"what mom's doing\\", I'd probably go mental.

  120. Definitely takes some getting used to the pain associated with tearing your hair out of a sensitive area, but the money saved on waxing makes it worthwhile.
  121. This product is amazing. I've been removing hair on my upper lip for years. I've used Nad's, Nair, and Sally's Hansen's wax strips, and I'm happy to say I'll never buy any of them ever again. Nad's caused acne, Nair is just awful, and Sally Hansen's worked ok but it's gooey, painful enough that I had to 'brace myself' to pull the strips off and I ended up cutting up the larger pieces for my upper lip.<br />The spring came in a padded envelope, the package squashed flat but the product undamaged. After a little maneuvering I figured out that holding it in a gentle U shape- not too close to a V!!!- with my thumbs facing each other, the U shape close to touching my face, almost straight up and down! and rolling it briskly back and forth worked perfectly to pull out every last little fine hair that often escapes my imperfect attempt at waxing...<br />It didn't hurt very much, less so I thought than waxing, but I've been tormenting my upper lip for years, so I thought I'd try it on a place that I'd never shorn, along my chin and it was a little more painful but not much.<br />The hair re-growth is absolutely normal with what I experienced waxing, I've had it about a month and used it once thoroughly and did a little retouch two weeks later. I experienced a little break out on my chin where I hadn't ever removed hairs, but my upper tougher lip was better overall for the wear!<br />I recommend this! You've got to fiddle with it to get it working right, if it pinches or doesn't pull out hair, try a different angle and roll!! It *will* work, and work great.
  122. I was skeptical of this product at first, but after reading all the positive reviews, I decided that I'd have to try it for myself. The product is super easy to use once you figure out which direction to roll it. I had some problems with some of the fine hairs breaking, but I was rolling it too fast. Once I slowed down, the hairs were pulling out at the root. It's definitely NOT painless, tears were rolling down my cheeks when I did my upper lip. But, it was so worth it! Upper lip looks great and the hair pulled out at the root! I also used it on the \\"fuzz\\" on my cheeks. The hair isn't completely gone yet, but considering this is my first try with the spring, I'm very happy! I plan on using this product a few times a week, just to keep up with it. I can't believe all the hair this little spring trapped. Overall fantastic product, great price! I'm ordering another for a spare and telling my friends as well!<br /><br />Edited to add: After I wrote this review, I broke out ALL OVER my face from using this product. I still use it but make sure to wipe the spring with alcohol pads before, during and after use. I also wipe my upper lip with an alcohol wipe prior to using the spring and use witch hazel after to close pores. This product is effective, but has not become any less painful to use!

The first time it does hurt, but so does any facial hair remover. But it is fast and easy, but with the long lasting effects of tweezing. It pulls the hair out at the root and leaves the skin smooth. I didn't get any irritation, it hurt a little but I rather have it hurt and work! The price is extremely affordable, especially for a product that you can use everyday and all the time! The first time is the hardest because there is the most hair to remove and it hurts the most. The next time you use it, it is just maintenance. I heard through videos I watched that it is best to use it a lot to keep the nerves use to it, because if you go a long time without using it then it will really hurt when you use it again. A+ product and A+ service, do yourself a favor and order it. It is the perfect solution and now I have a little less stress in my life. :-)

  168. I am 20 years old and have PCOS so I have hair on my face. It has gotten so unbearable I had to do something to get rid of it. I did my homework on this gadget and it seemed to be good. I got it in the mail today and went straight to the bathroom to use it! I love this thing! I think every Woman who wants to remove hair should use it! It hurts a little but considering that you are pulling hair out of your face, it is going to hurt. It is better than tweezing hair off your face because the REM spring gets it off fast and more pain free than tweezers. Bottom line buy it you will like it!   169. I won't really bother explaining how to use it...there are plenty of other users who have done a great job with that so far. As some of them have mentioned, it takes a little bit to figure out how to best use it, and I'm sure it's a little different for everyone. I would just like to say that it definitely grabs all hairs, no matter how short they are, so it's already better than waxing because you don't have to worry about letting hairs grow out to ridiculous or embarrassing lengths in between, and no appointments are neccessary. I would just like to recommend that the first time you use it, do it at night so that you're not walking around all day with a red face (I would assume most people will turn at least pink when pulling hair out of their skin). Also, be sure to wash, tone, and use a soothing non-comedogenic moisturizer afterward. You will have a lot open follicles, some which may have never been opened before, and you don't want anything icky getting in there and causing any sort of acne! Great product! I recommend it to anyone who wants to get rid of facial hair quickly, cheaply, and on their own schedule!<br /><br />Update, 4/3/13: Three years later, I still have my R.E.M. Spring. I clean it after every use with a quick rinse in a very mild soap water mix. I make a solution of a few drops of a mild dish soap (I use Mrs. Meyers, but any mild grease fighting soap will do) in a container, submerge the R.E.M. Spring in it, and open and close the R.E.M. spring bungee style while it is submerged. This helps dissolve your facial oils and get off any stubborn hairs stuck to said oil. Sometimes this isn't good enough, so I use an old toothbrush to scrub at and get in between the coils. Make sure you dry your Spring thoroughly if you do this! I lay a towel out, pull the Spring open bungee style again, and alternate between rolling it gently against the towel and shaking/banging it against the towel. You can hold it in front of a fan for a few seconds as well, if you'd like. I haven't had any rusting problems, but I do make sure to dry it thoroughly, and I do live in a dry climate.
  170. Seriously this is the best invention ever. I didn't ever realize how much hair I had on my face until this--I mean I knew everywhere else I was hairy like a man but this just verified how much facial hair I had lol and now I am stoked that there's a product out there I can use to keep looking like a girl! It is slightly confusing when you first get it on how it is used but I watched a quick TUTORIAL ON YOUTUBE and got it instantly. Once you know how to use it and which direction to roll it's the simplest yet most genius hair removal tool out there. Pain level feels a little like threading but it really does get better even after the second use. I 100% RECOMMEND TO THIS TO ANYONE AND EVERYONE. Such a smart device thank you thank you thank you! Maybe now I won't scare away guys with my facial hair--just my man voice instead.
  171. I have hair on my entire face. Its not really visible unless in direct bright sunlight. This product works to remove the hair just as it says. It was easy for me to figure out how to use it unlike some of the reviewers. The spring was pretty simple to use. --- Cons --- 1. This spring is EXTREMELY painful when used on the upper lip (mustache) area. If you leave it for a week and do it again, it will be just as painful, almost painful enough to make you throw it away and give up. 2. It did not remove the really light \\"baby hairs\\" from my forehead at all. This was the area that I bought the Spring Sprong for and it didn't work there. I think the hairs are too fine for this spring to work there. I have turned the spring in every possible direction, and it still wont remove the hairs. 3. It's kind of expensive for just a simple spring. 4. Its difficult to clean the hairs out of the inside of the spring. --- Pros --- 1. The REM Spring Sprong is very easy to use. 2. The pain is minimal in most areas 3. There has been no stubble or ingrown hairs on my face when using this product. (I've used it for a few months with not one ingrown hair, & I am prone to them) 4. You can use it in the privacy of your own home, ( I use it while watching television) 5. You don't have to wait for hair to reach a certain length before using, you can use it every day to get the random hairs that have grown. (I use it a few time a week just so it will be less painful than if I waited a couple of weeks and all the hair grows back) Overall, I would recommend this product if you have hair on your whole face that you want to remove. If you only want to remove hair above the lip, mustache, I suggest you just get it waxed because its less painful and time consuming. - UPDATE I have been using the Spring for 6 months now and the most important things are to use it often to reduce the pain and make sure that your face is washed and exfoliated before and after each use. One time I used itright after work without washing my face and I had a bad breakout.
  172. This product is a little swirly miracle for people with sensitive skin. Waxing leaves the area around my mouth broken out in unsightly pimples and I am convinced threading was used as a form of torture back in the day...its unnecessarily painful! I wasn't too keen on the idea of using a hair removal cream on my face and after tweezing about 10 hairs I gave up...who has time for all of that? I started using a bikini trimmer, but it was never as smooth as I had hoped and had a prickly feel within two days. I was nervous about the long term effects of shaving so I tried to do it sparingly. After researching my remaining options, I came across the REM spring. I was certain that it was going to be painful but I had tried almost everything else, so for 9.99 it seemed worth a shot...<br /><br />When the product arrived I was so excited to give it a try. I had watched you tube videos after purchasing to try and get the hang of the motion needed for the spring to be effective. I'm not going to go into how to use it, just you tube \\"spring hair removal\\" videos and there are plenty of tutorials at your disposal. I found that it was much easier to learn how to use it by watching videos than the instructions provided in the box when you purchase the spring. There is also a video on the REM spring website that demonstrates how to use their product.<br /><br />Anyway, I plugged in my headphones and took off to the bathroom to use my new hair removal tool. It grasps the hair at the root and with a quick twist pulls them out. It didn't hurt anywhere near as much as I had expected. The portion of the upper lip that had a quick sting to it was right below your nose, but it was definitely bearable. My eyes watered when I did this section, but it was more the location than the intensity of the pain that caused it. 15 minutes later and my lip was the smoothest it has ever been after hair removal, without redness or little welts forming. I am certain that it will get quicker with practice and frequency of use, but I am beyond pleased with the results of my first time!! I am recommending this to everyone of my gf's that suffers through threading of the upper lip!

  187. It has always been a joke between my sister and me that we might be part Sasquatch. Seriously, we're pretty hairy. Luckily, it is not dark hair, but light colored peach fuzz hair that coats our faces. When the sun hits us it looks like we've got halos around our faces. Not pretty - and as we've gotten older it seems to be getting THICKER and LONGER... Ugh. In my 30 years, I've tried a lot of things to get rid of this hair. I've use things like Nair, plucking, and waxing. Nair left my face too smooth and then the stubble came back in. Not attractive (neither was the skin burn from the Nair). Plucking is just not realistic. I don't have that much time in my day. Waxing worked, but it left my face too hairless and irritated - and then the stubble came back, again not pretty. So, when I got the spring sprong, I immediately tried it out. I was impressed! What I like is that it doesn't take out all of the hair (although I'm sure if you did it enough you could get rid of most of it). What it does do is remove enough of it so that I look like a normal human being, not a Sasquatch. And, when the hair grow back in it is not stubbly at all!!! Now, I have to tell you that it does hurt, just a bit. Nothing like waxing, though! And it does leave a little redness, but it goes away really quickly. I love it!

  204. I've been looking for some type of hair removal because I've been using creams that have ended up burning my skin and leaving burn marks (which are now fading thankfully). It doesn't hurt as much as plucking because it pulls the hair out fast by the root and I have thick hair sadly. The only complaint I would make is that my hands get tired and that it sometimes can't pick up the tiny, tiny hairs that are shorter than peach fuzz. But I just go with my tweezers to pick up anything that it missed. I like to use the Spring Sprong while watching a movie, I don't even need to have a mirror, I just keep rolling it over the areas that I know have hair and it keeps pulling them out like a pro. Cleaning it wasn't hard at all, simply bend the spring in a U shape and you can blow out the hairs that you see lodged inside (they usually gather up at the end tips of the spring). Overall I'm glad I bought it and coming from a tom-boy type girl who never really buys this stuff, it is absolutely worth it. Horray for my first review =)

  210. I wasn't expecting much from this thing, especially since it only cost $13 and was simplistic in nature. However, it's far exceeded my expectations so far, and then some. I use it on my upper lip, cheeks and chin. What I love: - Cost effective! No batteries to replace. No wax to deal with or pay for. No going off to the salon to pay a fortune on a regular basis to have someone else do it, and there's no wasting gas in order to get there. I'd also much rather spend $13 to replace a tool that works, rather than $20-$60 on a machine that might fail for various reasons. - It may not be as fast, but it's far more gentle on the skin vs. waxing. This hurts, but only from the hair being pulled out rather than my skin along with it. It was also much gentler on my face than my electric epilator that I use for my body. - No blemishes! I sometimes get breakouts when I pluck or wax my face, although it's not every time. I thought for sure I'd break out, but had no problems. In fact, the few I had before using it disappeared the next day, which may mean my products are working better. Who knows! - Gets faster and more pain-free the more you do it. Since hair tends to grow in cycles, I'm doing it once a week or so, just to keep on top of things (I also feel it hurts less when they're shorter). - Grabbed both baby-fine hairs and super-short coarse ones, including on zee chin - though it took some time to sort the right angles on some sections. - It's spiffy and portable. If there's ever a zombie apocalypse, I'll be set in my cave or non-powered hidey hole. Tips: - Make sure you try it from different angles, and try to turn the device into an upright U-shape if some hairs aren't being plucked up, or even somewhat straight. It also helps to make the silly faces for difficult-to-get hairs. - I clean mine with anti-bacterial soap and dry it. - Make sure to exfoliate your skin one to two times a week, especially around the time you use this. I use a scrub, sonic brush or enzyme peel (mostly a gentle peel), depending on my mood/circumstances. Wash your face before and after with a non-irritating soap. - Always use a clean pillowcase the night you use this, and change it at least once a week. - Wash your hands if you have to touch your face, or avoid doing so right after. - It may help to avoid harsh, alcohol-based toners, since it could irritate the skin and cause bumps. I use Mychelle Fruit Enzyme Mist, which is more of a tonique to restore pH balance after I wash my face (and it gently exfoliates) - though I'm sure any kind will do. - Check Youtube to see how others use devices similar to this
  211. First, let's be real. It's essentially tweezing many, many hairs at once. It does cause pain. If you can't handle pain, don't buy this. If you can handle pain, this is a no brainer. Think of how much money you save over time! It is easy to use, causes less irritation than waxing or chemicals, and there is no goop left on your face! Also, I would only wax areas that made sense with a strip, for many reasons, including cost. With this, there is none of that fear. Remove where/whenever you like! Sit back and watch your favorite sitcom and tear the hair right out of your face. :-)
  212. So...after I got the hang of it it worked...with some time and effort anyways. The only thing I dislike it the pimples on each side of my mouth I got. Part of the reason I wanted to try a new product was because the cream remover would sometimes cause redness that could last over a day in the same area. So to compare cream vs. coil...they both leave their mark. Cream is faster and less painful. Coil seems to keep hair away longer. It all depends on what side effect is worse for you. To be honest, having little pimples next to my mouth probably gives people the wrong impression, I would rather stick with the cream and save up for lazer treatments.

From a teenage girl, I have always been afraid to kiss I guy I dated due to the fact that my upper lip and chin might scare him away because of those pesky little tiny coarse facial hair! Yeah I'd have to tweeze each and every one a night before I have to go out anywhere. It came to a point where I just gave up going out and will head out atleast once a week. Staying indoors and away from the natural sun light outside made me depressed and my self esteem was buried all the way deep into the earth's soil! I'm fair skinned and my hair is naturally dark. So the intensity of my facial hair would look so horrifying for a female. I thought I'd never have a normal life til one day I needed to help myself and get on with my life, make a change. I researched online and I found this! Came in the mail and I started to make a difference in my life. I'm so used to this product and I am so thankful. This is amazing, anyone who is suffering from what I went through SHOULD REALLY PURCHASE THIS! It worked from me and now I have a higher self esteem and I'm not insecure anymore. I go out everyday whenever I want to. Now I can finally look for a job because I got my confidence back and this product is great!
  214. Fuzzy Wuzzy wuz a... not me! Ha! This little REM Spring for facial hair removal is absolutely fantastic. UPS delivered it less than an hour ago and I'm fuzz-less already. To you Ladies who wrote about not finding success with this little Spring, please be patient and keep trying. Let me tell you about my experience: I read the reviews here last week before I ordered the Spring and when it arrived today the tips from these reviews were forgotten. Off I went with my Spring, magnifying mirror, tweezers, and eye glasses to find hairless happiness. I read the instructions that came with the Spring and went from there. The Spring was turned into a U for most of the time in use, and the ends were twirled in one direction or another or the same while I experimented (this was due to a lack of coordination rather than a science-based determination to experiment). Voila! The little hairs from my upper lip, lower lip, and chin are gone. Am not exactly sure which mode of holding the Spring worked but something did. I'm not advocating going about this willy-nilly, but if you spend a bit of time you will succeed. Don't be too locked into the how of it. Try staying with the U shape and turning the ends to see what happens... play with it. You will be sooo glad you did. My upper lip is slightly tender (emphasis on 'slightly'). That's not a problem for me. This little Spring is heaven-sent: it works and I am grateful. Thank you, Amazon.com, for these reviews. It is unlikely I would have ordered a Spring to remove facial hair if I'd not read what these other ladies had experienced.
  215. After researching facial hair removal, I took a chance on this and love it. It stings the first time you try it but then you get familiar with the areas of your face and which sting more than others. Try this before any other hair removal treatments. You won't be sorry.
  216. I was looking for an alternative to bleaches, since I have very sensitive skin, and stumbled upon the R.E.M. Spring. I'll be the first to admit that I was skeptical. Especially because it looks so simple. Truth be told, it's wonderful! Don't believe that it doesn't hurt, it does. The same as plucking. However the spring is a lot faster and gentler. I've been using it for a few months and have no irritation. I'm a fan.
  217. You know what? This little tool really, really works. I wish they'd take the word 'painless' out of their advertising though, because it certainly isn't. As anyone who's tweezed or waxed knows, ripping a bunch of tiny hairs out by their roots at once is anything but 'painless.' If you're like me, prior to this tool, you had one of three options for hair removal. 1) Use that awful Nair for Face stuff that takes off a layer of your skin along with the hair, and walk around for three days with a red goatee and irritated skin. 2) Face the pain of waxing it off and still walk around with a red mustache and irritated skin afterwards. 3) Tweeze each and every little hair, one by one, consuming a day and a half if you want to get everything. Each option more unappealing than the last. But this! One little tool you shell out [...] bucks for one time, that you can use without a mirror, sitting in front of the TV, and within a half hour or so be nice and smooth, with no irritated and red skin. SWEET! This little tool is so awesome, I want to tell everyone about it. And it's so simple! No waxes, no tweezers, no smelly creams! It *is* tricky to learn how to use, however, I will say that. Don't give up, however. Just experiment. The most important thing is the turning of the handles, so that the hair is caught in the spring and literally being twisted off. And it doesn't have to be in a sharp U shape like in the picture. I've gotten bunch of hair in a wide crescent before. Give it a try if you're tired of the waxing Nairing red face thing! You won't regret it.

  229. I am a 25 yr old African American woman. I've been blessed with a gorgeous head of THICK hair that runs down my back and unfortunately a gorgeous face full of hair that goes from my unibrow (even above that I have a pretty fuzzy forehead that I took care of by doing an upside down crescent bend and rolling downward) to underneath my chin, on my neck. I have struggled since the age 13. I didn't know any better because the women in my family didn't talk openly about being hairy and I was too embarrassed to ask. Come to find out as an adult they are freakin hairy too! It started with shaving and went to waxing and tweezing my uni, cheeks, mustache, chin, jaw line, and neck.. in more recent years. Let me tell u that I WAS DESPERATE. This was interfering with my whole life. I didn't want to go outside! Especially not in the daylight. I could feel peoples eyes on me in the grocery store line, in the line at the post office, sitting next to me at dinner, etc. From a certain distance people smiled or guys would look and when they got close enough to see my extra hair, they became disgusted with me or would look away. Waxing was breaking me out and tweezing 1 by 1 was OK but it took too long in the mirror and I could never get every hair because on top of having coarse hair was long ass peach fuzz... UGH!! SO the shipping was ok. I ordered on Sunday and got it on Friday. I cleaned it with a paper towel and rubbing alcohol 1st. Then washed my face and let in dry. This thing was so painful for me that my eyes were constantly tearing and teeth clenching. I decided to do my normal 1 by 1 tweeze job on as many of the really coarse hairs first and then I went over all the areas with the spring. It was still painful but bearable. Since I'm sooo hairy I didn't expect to get it all the 1st night. I did as much as I could bear that night, and followed the next night. MY FACE IS VIRTUALLY HAIR FREE AND SMOOTH NOW!!!!! I use the spring every nightjust to catch any strays and keep my face smooth. My skin is sensitive so it does get red and a little swollen from all the removal but that goes away in about 15-30 mins. I usually hold a cold bottle of water on the areas to soothe and that works magic. I was going to give this 4 stars because of the pain but I HAD a ware wolf face so there is no way it wasn't going to be painful. It pulls every single little hair from the root. You can try less of a U shape (more like a crescent shape) and also try rolling in different directions because hair grows at all different angles sometimes. If you have like 4 or 5 hairs on your chin I would say to save your 20 bucks and tweeze those suckers. The mustache was unbearable for me so I just shave it...but that's like a walk in the park for this gal. Give it a try! If you're really hairy just try what I did and you won't regret it. Good luck all!! I hope this helps someone. XOXO

  240. Product is great at removing facial hair. So easy to use. Yes, it stings a little when the hairs get pulled out, but no more than when using tweezers. You get used to it. Advantage is that many hairs get pulled at once, rather than one at a time, and you don't have to use a mirror. Love that it gets fine, fluffy hair on cheeks and jaw line. If it's not grabbing the hair, try moving the spring in different directions, and also adjusting the shape of the \\"U\\". If it's more of gentle curve than a proper U-shape, it might catch the hairs better because the space between the spring is smaller. Works for me! Also, for those who complain about in-grown hairs and red bumps - clean your skin before using and use an astringent right after. You need to close your pores. If you notice some red bumps, scrub your face - a little exfoliation usually works for me.

It worked really well on my cheeks and chin, but I had a harder time removing the hair from the neck area and my upper lip. I think the hair on my upper lip didn't fully grow out, and that's why it didn't work as well there. My overall comments about this product are that it's a great alternative to waxing. If your skin gets irritated easily, I recommend putting Aloe Vera on your face after using the product - just make sure it's the kind with no alcohol or fragrance. I recommend buying this product - not a waste of money.

  275. This thing worked wonders for me. About 5 years ago, after getting a terribly upclose picture taken, I was absolutely horrified to see that I had a beard! I have a lot of fine and light colored hair on my jawline, but it's longer than most women's. It's not terribly noticeable (I didn't think) except for in direct sunlight and at certain angles. But it has made me very self-conscious for years. I would always try to keep my hair down to cover the sides of my face. I never did anything about it because I feared that it would grow back thicker and darker. I use Sally Hansen hair remover for my upper lip once a week but using it for my whole face would have been expensive, time consuming and annoying, plus that stuff has an unpleasant smell. I didn't want to remove all of the hair on my face, as after doing my upper lip, when I sweat it seems to bead because there is no hair to catch it. Plus I thought it would look weird to be completly hairless.<br /><br />I am getting married in 6 weeks and have been absolutely dreading the upclose outdoor pictures-our venue is a community park and getting pictures at dusk will be unavoidable. I still wasn't planning on doing anything about it because I didn't want to make a lifelong committment to whole-face hair removal-only planning on making a lifelong committment to the man I'm marrying! A couple of weeks ago I saw some infomerical (can't recall the product, maybe NoNo), so I went online to look at reviews and that led me to read up on an assortment of products. I came across some at home machines that were awfully expensive ($400+ refills) and weren't supposed to be used on the face (although that wouldn't have stopped me). I have also researched electrolosis but found out that I wouldn't be a good candidate because my hair is light.<br /><br />Eventually I stumbled onto this product and I poured over the reviews and ordered that day. I was so excited for it to come that I ripped it out of the box. I went to work with a 2x mirror in a well lit room. It did hurt-like others have said, it's comprable to tweezing (I think it might hurt a little less). Tears welled up in my eyes a couple of times but it wasn't like I was about to scream out in pain. I tried to do my moustache but since I used the hair remover cream less than a week ago I don't think it was long enough to pull out. It took me a little bit of trial and error to get this to grab and remove hair but I knew not to give up. After doing my whole face, it was red (like when I pluck my eyebrows) but I put some moisturizer on and went to bed and woke up with smooth silkly, normal skin. It does look a little dry though, I probably should have reapplied the moisturizer in the AM.<br /><br />I love that I can do this in the convenience of my home. I will try to give an update as to how often I have to use this product to maintain my face as it is now-not completely hairless, there are VERY short fine hairs remaining, you know like most normal people! I plan to do it twice a week. This is the cheapest, easiest, most ingenious product for facial hair removal I've seen! I keep looking at my face in mirrors from the angles I used to dread and it makes me so happy. While I can't say I'm looking forward to getting a bunch of pictures taken of me, it's no longer because of my facial hair!<br /><br />I can't wait to tell all of my female friends and family members about this!! And thanks to everyone else who left reviews, you made me try this product and I am so grateful that I did! I am not big on reviewing, but I felt I had to add my story since I got a lot out of everyone else's. For other women with my type of facial hair, I can't urge you enough to try this product. At $13, what's there to lose??<br /><br />Update: I used this for the second time about a week after the first try. It was not nearly as painful, I didn't even bat an eye-probably because you are pulling much less hair. It is tough to do your chin, I'm still trying to figure out the most efficient angles, etc. I don't think I'll have to use this more than once a week for maintenance, which is awesome! Oh, and it did end up making me break out on my jaw line by my ears. But they weren't pimples, just bumps and they went a way within a couple of days.
  276. I was really excited to try this hair removal tool out, because I have very sensitive skin and haven't been able to remove those fine hairs on my upper lip without lots of irritation. I use exfoliating/anti-aging products on my face that aren't recommended to be used for a while before waxing, so on top of making the appointments, and finding a babysitter and paying for the service, waxing is really inconvenient for me. Hair removal creams smell rotten and give me a rash every time, plus the hair grows back super fast.<br /><br />I washed my face first and then tried this out, hesitantly. Let me tell you, after doing my whole upper lip...the faster you move this tool, the better. Since I was kind of afraid of the pain, I was slow in my movements and GUHHH it made my eyes water and it really hurt. I put a cold pack on my skin to help numb it a little and that sort of worked. But then I just grew a pair and really went for it, twisting the tool up and down quickly, and it hurt less that way. I really like the way the ends of the tool twist around easily, and because they are kind of tapered at the end it's not at all awkward to use. The tool has a very tight spring so it got all of the fine hairs I could see and some I couldn't. It hurt the most next to my lip and next to my nose. But now that I've gotten it over with, I'm happy with the result...there are some teeny tiny white hairs left, and this is why the final result wins out over waxing to me. We have tiny tiny fuzz all over our face, but waxing for me removes all of that too and makes my upper lip look kind of shiny and weird compared to the rest of my face. But this tool is capable of leaving just enough tiny fuzz that it's not obvious you removed the hair from your upper lip. I think I could have removed it all if I just sat for a while watching T.V. while I did it, but I got the all of longer darker hairs that bothered me in a short time.<br /><br />I'm glad I chose this product over the others because of the way the ends are shaped and because of the quality of the spring, even if it is a little more expensive. I will be buying these as gifts for all my girlfriends!
  277. I am a Latina with dark facial hair ESP on my cheeks, jaw area. I was getting so uncomfortable being out and would actually position myself so that my less hairy side would be exposed. I mean really I'm not exaggerating - I was thinking about shaving cause it was so gross. My sister mentioned this little product she has been using and so I thought - I have nothing to lose. The fist time was no big deal. I just followed my natural instinct on how to twist the rod . Don't think about it too much. I didnt have to curve it so much . In some areas it was almost straight. You can tell its working by hearing the satisfying pulling of the hair. It doesn't hurt me on the jaw but the mustache kills! I use it everyday but I have skipped a day-you MIT need to use it less if your growth is slower. Please don't hesitate - I would pay 5 times the amount for how much better I feel about myself.
  278. I was definitely a skeptic before purchasing this item, but I figured..what the heck did I have to lose? I spend ~$10 plus tip and gas just to travel to the salon to get my upper lip waxed when I get my eyebrows done. This little spring is such a savior. In fact, I left it at home and I'm away for about 4 weeks, so I'm seriously considering buying a back-up since I love using this spring to remove facial hair. It works fantastic for pulling hair, and you just have to get used to it. The pain is there, but after 1-2x of using it, you will get used to it. If you've ever epilated before, this is similar except you can control the direction and way the hairs are coming out. I will say - be careful while using this on your upper lip under your nose because pulling a nose hair out on accident is no joke! It hurts!<br /><br />I would highly recommend this product for removing upper lip hair as well as facial hair. I don't think this would work on coarse, thicker hair, I stick to epilating/waxing/shaving for those. But since this saves me around $10 and I can use it everyday, it's a must-have in my book!<br /><br />Also - after the first time I used it, I broke out on my chin area and bottom of my cheeks since I had never removed hair there before (not unbearable, and I actually have acne prone skin). I would suggest washing your face after using this but don't give up on it. I stopped breaking out after continually using this.

  283. After reading the product and customer reviews, I was able to catch on quickly and got right to removing the hairs on my upper lip, chin, and cheek areas. My skin was a bit red afterward, but the irritation was gone after a few minutes. It did a great job of removing the fine hairs (which is what make up most of my face fuzz), but I had to use tweezers for the hairs that were really short and the ones that were embedded just barely under my skin and close to surfacing (my stylist calls them pepper spots). The pain takes getting used to (it feels like waxing without the goop), but overall, this is a great product for removing facial hair.

  288. I bought the REM Spring Sprong about 6 months ago. I use it once a week. It is very easy to use once you play around with it a bit. I use it mainly for my upper lip and for my pesky chin hairs. It works well to pull them out. You can see that it is working because all of the hairs are stuck in the spring. That being said, it is very easy to clean as well. The only trouble I have had with it is that it does not always pluck the coarse, dark hairs. I sometimes have to tweeze those regularly. But, it is a lot better than having to tweeze all of the hairs one at a time. It does leave some redness, but that goes away pretty quickly. Is there some pain? Yes. When you are ripping hair from your body, you are going to have some pain. This pain is manageable. The more you use it, the more you get used to it.   289. I just received my REM Spring in the mail yesterday and I am amazed at how quickly I was able to get it to work. I watched several youtube tutorials on this product while I was waiting to receive it and that helped. This product works so well! It pulls the hair out by the root and you don't even need a mirror. I don't mind using tweezers, but I have a hard time seeing all of the hair, either because my eyesight is no longer 20/20 or the location makes it difficult to see and tweeze at the same time. The REM Spring pulls out multiple hairs at once and again, no need to see what you are doing. I used it last night while watching a movie without a mirror or even a light on! In a nutshell, you bend it into a \\"U\\" shape and then twist the ends in a circlular motion, while running the spring across your face. To be clear, it is painful!!! A few times, I had to \\"untwist\\" the spring by turning the ends in the opposite direction to \\"let go\\" of the hair, because I didn't feel as though I could take the pain! All in all, I really love this product and have been thinking of ways ot reduce the pain. My first thought is to use an after-sunburn type gel on your face first to help numb the surface and ease the pain. That and pop an ibuprofen about 20 minutes beforehand. I will have to experiment and will update my review with the results!
  290. I purchased this item with some doubt in my mind, because many hair removal products just don't seem to work for me. I purchased the REM Spring and in the first evening of getting it, I had managed to remove all of the hair that had been bothering me since I was a kid! It's quick, and because I already use an epilator regularly, this was relatively painless in comparison. The REM Spring is also great because it's so small and portable, doesn't use electricity, and its stainless-steel body has no disposable parts to damage the environment. It's also easy to sanitize. I have been using this for about two months now and have had no problems.<br /><br />I think the biggest advantage of this product is that you don't necessarily have to be squinting into a magnifying mirror to remove the hair; I can use it while watching TV or reading. It took me only about 5 minutes to figure out how to use it according to the directions, and I absolutely love this thing. Effects on hair and hair regrowth are the same as tweezing or epilating. A friend wanted to go get facial threading done, but this is cheaper and you can do it yourself.<br /><br />Cons:<br />-cannot reliably do eyelid area below eyebrows (the instructions advise against it because you could catch your eyelashes. If this happens, pull on both ends of the spring to release it.)<br />-the grips at the end are a bit small, but not that it changes the effectiveness of the item<br />-I'm not really sure how to clean the inside of the spring, but that also doesn't affect the usage at all<br /><br />Pros:<br />-inexpensive<br />-sustainable, long-term product made of stainless steel<br />-no chemicals, unlike using hair-removal creams<br />-no disposable parts (unlike razor cartridges)<br />-sturdy<br />-tiny and portable<br />-easy to use<br />-same amountof pain as with tweezing/epilating<br />-very fast to remove large amount of hair as opposed to tweezing<br /><br />Definitely give this a try, because I'd never heard of this before and it's absolutely great!

  305. This product IS threading without the difficulty. It is so easy (unless you don't read the two step directions first). Simply make a U shape and then twist your pincher fingers (making sure that your left and right are both going outward or inward at the same time). It gets everything! It even got the fine hair! I love this thing it is so quick and you get the hang of it after the first time (or about 10 minutes of playing with it). It is def NOT precise enough to do eyebrows!! Do not even try!   328. This tool really works. It's low tech, so nothing to break and it's super easy to use. Smart little gadget!
  329. WOW! I am in love with this product! I want to tell all my girlfriends! Where has this been all my life? Once you get the hang of this it rips all those nasty hairs out sooo much quicker than tweezing! It does hurt but no more than tweezing and my skin is red for a little bit but it goes away within a couple of hours. When I first tried this using the others reviewers suggestion of clockwise and counterclockwise it didn't work so well but after experimenting it worked best for me to turn the handles in and put the spring below and move up. I go in different directions for hair that grows in different directions. The hairs that were not catching I found it helpful to pull out once i got a hold of them similiar to tweezing. Buy this product you won't be sorry!
  330. This thing works if you can get past the pain. It will make your eyes tear up. I dread using, but it works great.

Even when I pull the spring out to blow away the hairs, it holds well. Overall, i'm pretty impressed and will certainly keep using it in replacement for threading or waxing.   334. I was really disappointed when I first tried to use the Spring Sprong; it had such great reviews it I ordered it and it hadn't really occurred to me that it was going to be a HUGE problem getting it to work for me. On top of having pretty bad arthritis to begin with, I have joint replacements in my left hand and my left thumb is fused at the knuckle. Somehow being bionic managed to slip my mind as I hit the \\"buy with one click\\" button.<br /><br />I do have some pinch grip left in my hands but the smaller something is, the harder it is for me to grip. Try as I might spinning this thing in different rotations just wasn't going to happen. I looked at the tool again and realized the tapered ends were the problem if they were just wider somehow I could get a better grip on them and maybe get it to work. Frustrated, I consulted my toolbox to see if anything in there could be of use.<br /><br />Strapping tape!<br /><br />I cut off a small section and trimmed it to about two-thirds the height of the \\"handles\\" of the Spring Sprong. I placed the edge of the tape near the thinnest part of the tapered handle and started winding. Before long I had built up what looked more like a Q-tip bulb shape on each end. The new \\"handles\\" were much easier to get a grip on and I gave it another try.<br /><br />It worked!<br /><br />I think I might be able to use the same handle building idea with something other than tape so it will look a little better but for now at least it gets results; I am still pretty slow at this but it *does* work.

  346. I ordered this because I read about it in Oprah's O Magazine and they loved it. When I received it, I read the directions and even went to the REM website and watched a video of how to use it, but I couldn't get it to work for me. I almost gave up and thought about tossing it, but then I decided to experiment since there were other people who liked it.<br />Here's what worked:<br />1.) You don't necessarily have to bend the spring into a tight U shape as shown in the pictures (you can also use it bent just a little into a wide rounded U shape).<br />2.) Lay the spring against your skin just below where you want to remove the hair.<br />3.) As you slowly move the spring upward, twirl the right hand fingers clockwise and the left hand fingers counter-clockwise. If you twirl them the opposite way, no hairs get grabbed (this was the main thing I needed to figure out and the instructions didn't explain it).<br />4.) Doing this grips the hairs and pulls them out, and yes, it does hurt for a split second but no longer than that and it doesn't leave your skin at all pink or red or irritated. I suspect it hurts more when you first start using it, but after multiple uses, I'm thinking it will hurt less.<br />I cannot understand why the REM company doesn't explain how important it is to twirl your fingers in the right direction. I was ready to toss the thing. I should add that the hairs I want to grip are not at all unusual (just your average thing). So I'm giving this 4 stars instead of 5 only because I had to figure this out for myself, whereas the company could have done a better job of explaining how to use it. Once you figure this stuff out, the spring itself does a great job and is worth 5 stars for how it actually works.<br /><br />Update: I have used this for quite a while now, and it by far hurts the most the first time you use it, I guess because it is grabbing the most hairs that first time. I find that I need to use it 2 or 3 times a week, and when you do that, you're only picking up those hairs that are long enough to be grabbed. It hurts much less because there are less hairs than the first time (I think individual hairs grow at different rates). So definitely do not judge this based on the first-time level of pain - it's no big deal and I LOVE the way it works. I have read what other people said about turning \\"both hands in, then both hands out\\" and that accomplishes the same thing I recommended (right hand clockwise, left hand counterclockwise) - that accomplishes \\"both hands in\\" and that is the sweep that grabs the hairs and pulls them out. The \\"both hands out\\" doesn't grab any hairs.<br /><br />Another update: I'm still using this 2-3 times a week and I love it! I have noticed one additional thing that I thought I would mention. I have a magnifying mirror which I use occasionally and I've noticed that there are a few hairs that grow in somewhat different directions from the others. Most of my hairs get grabbed when I sweep upwards at them from below, but there are a few that grow in an upward direction, or from right to left or left to right, and those weren't getting grabbed with the others. So now I sweep at the hairs from every possible direction: upwards, downwards, right to left, left to right, diagonally, etc. This picks up those remaining hairs. This also should help if you're trying to get hairs on a curvy surface like your chin area. Just remember that whatever direction you're sweeping, the right hand goes clockwise and the left hand goes counter clockwise.you're only picking up those hairs that are long enough to be grabbed. It hurts much less because there are less hairs than the first time (I think individual hairs grow at different rates). So definitely do not judge this based on the first-time level of pain - it's no big deal and I LOVE the way it works. I have read what other people said about turning \\"both hands in, then both hands out\\" and that accomplishes the same thing I recommended (right hand clockwise, left hand counterclockwise) - that accomplishes \\"both hands in\\" and that is the sweep that grabs the hairs and pulls them out. The \\"both hands out\\" doesn't grab any hairs.<br /><br />Another update: I'm still using this 2-3 times a week and I love it! I have noticed one additional thing that I thought I would mention. I have a magnifying mirror which I use occasionally and I've noticed that there are a few hairs that grow in somewhat different directions from the others. Most of my hairs get grabbed when I sweep upwards at them from below, but there are a few that grow in an upward direction, or from right to left or left to right, and those weren't getting grabbed with the others. So now I sweep at the hairs from every possible direction: upwards, downwards, right to left, left to right, diagonally, etc. This picks up those remaining hairs. This also should help if you're trying to get hairs on a curvy surface like your chin area. Just remember that whatever direction you're sweeping, the right hand goes clockwise and the left hand goes counter clockwise.

  377. I bought this product over a year ago, and couldn't get the hang of how to use it.
