Oh my gosh, I'm sooo glad I did. The spring REALLY works! You just have to practice to see what works for you, don't give up if at first you don't succeed. What worked for me was to use less of a U shape sometimes almost a straight spring with only the handles turned down, twirling the handles between thumb and index finger (thumbs moving towards each other), rolling it slowly over cheeks chin,lip, or wherever I need it with medium to light pressure....VOILA, 'FUZZ\\" free. The first time took the longest and was slightly uncomfortable, rather like little stings when the hairs are extracted. Remember, that hairs grow at different rates, and what you can't catch today will be long enough to catch tomorrow. If it's not long enough to pull it's not long enough to be noticeable,so no big whup.<br />I do a daily over-all, takes 5 minutes, MAYBE, bonus; there seems to be a lot less hair growing back! Face is SUPER SMOOTH and I haven't experienced redness or irritation. Have introduced family member to the R.E.M. spring and she loves it too.<br />I'm not a review writer as a rule, but this product has worked so well... no more burned skin as well as no more problems with facial hair, I just had to share.
  378. When the R.E.M. Spring Facial Hair Remover arrived I wasn't quite sure how to work it because the included instructions were minimal to say the least. It does take a little experimenting to get it to work, but with the help of some amazon reviews and a video review (also Amazon) I was able to get the hang of it.<br /><br />What worked for me was holding it in a U shape and I turned the side in my right hand clockwise and the one in my left hand counter-clockwise (That is, I was turning both sides so that they were going the same direction). It worked best when going against the hair follicle, slowly and firmly moving the spring across the area. I'd also like to note that you don't necessarily have to have the spring bent into a U shape to make it work. For me it worked, when it was in the U shape as shown in the picture, but in other variations as well, slightly bent, at different angles, it even worked flat and straight on some areas-though it worked best in a U or semi-bent shape.<br /><br />Point is, you'll probably have to play with it a bit to get the hang of it and see what works for you. It hurts at first, but honestly it was more of a mild irritant for me, not too bad, kind of like when you first start plucking your brows. It definitely does not hurt as much as waxing does, and the pain passed quickly. However it will probably vary from person to person as to how much pain you experience.<br /><br />The Bottom Line is It worked and got rid of almost all those pesky facial hairs I had in a very short amount of time with minimal pain. I am absolutely thrilled with this product, finally a facial hair remover that actually does what it says it will!

  382. I had high hopes based on the glowing reviews, but it just doesn't live up to the accolades. The product works similarly to other epilators from the past twenty years or so: a curved coil rotates, pinching and pulling hairs out. The difference is that you control the rotation, rather than an electric motor. This is great for those light, barely noticeable hairs on the upper lip and sides of the face,but if you have the coarser, darker hair on the chin and neck, it will have to grow to a noticeable stubble before it is long enough for the spring to catch. The whole point of epliators is to prevent the noticeable stubble in the first place. To recap: more useful for the light hairs that can grow longer without being noticed, not good for the coarse, dark hairs that are noticeable the moment they grow past the epidermis. No quite a fail, but not quite a miracle either.

  429. Ok, I never write reviews for anything. I'm a half African half Puerto Rican 26 year old with PCOS. I have coarse hair, very coarse stubborn hair that refuses to part with the follicles. Stubborn enough to not be picked up by waxing, or a battery-powered facial epilator. I had been looking for alternatives, when I found this little guy.<br /><br />I read the reviews posted and even factored in the negative ones. I'm familiar to threading (I get my brows threaded) but for some reason threading on my face doesn't work as well, so I was a little skeptical. That and, how could something so simple be able to rip the hair out?<br /><br />So I order this, it gets in the mail and I rip the package open. I immediately wash my face and make sure to pat it with a very warm towel and set to work. I had already seen the youtube tutorials and the instructions. I wasn't surprised to find that it caught hairs... what I was amazed and delighted to feel was that half an hour later my chin was virtually hair-free. Tried it on one side of my stache, it's gone, it's not even red (I really think the hot towel helped). The tricky spots (under the chin) you have to play with the angles and you know it's working when the thing just grabs it.<br /><br />I'm entering my opinion because I really do know this product works. Like those have said before me, you have to be patient with it, play with it, and be prepared to have some pain. ANYTHING that yanks hair straight out of the follicle is gonna hurt (Uh, duh?) and if you have stubble you're probably trying to tug at new hair or you have to play more with the angle and the closeness of the spring to the face.<br /><br />For me, this product wins on all accounts. I don't have to look like Chewbacca nor am I doomed to spending money on batteries, creams, wax that rips everything but your hair, and it's relatively fast and easy, and you can do it in the privacy of your own home.<br /><br />If you suffer from coarse hair and understand there willbe some pain, this is a very worthwhile investment. I'm buying 2 more as backups :D
  430. I have tried waxing, threading, emjoi hair remover, and electrolysis -- I could have saved a lot of time, money and pain if I had purchased this earlier.<br /><br />I have a lot of \\"fuzz\\", up to 3/8-1/2\\"long, and some darker and longer hairs on my upper lip and chin/neck. I also have very sensitive skin that easily breaks out. I had to schedule my threading/waxing/emjoi when I would have at least 4 days without seeing people! Each time, I would get red spots that turned into pimples all over the area. I used every cream that claimed a solution -- nothing worked. So for 12 years, I just lived with break-outs in order to have an unhairy face. Electrolysis I could afford only for those dark hairs, and that gave me bumps but no pimples. But the cost--ugh!!<br /><br />Then I found this product -- I was skeptical of the glowing reviews, but the price made it worthwhile to try.<br /><br />UNBELIEVABLE!!!<br /><br />Yes, it takes a few tries to develop a method that works for you, but you know when you have it right -- and other reviews/tapes offer suggestions, but for me it was just trial and error for a few minutes.<br /><br />Yes, it stings as it pulls the hair, but big deal-- it is nothing to threading or waxing or emjoi or electrolysis. And it is entirely in your control. If it gets too much -- stop for a few minutes and go back later. As other reviewers have mentioned, the first time is the worst.<br /><br />Now as to the result -- it does tend to break off the fuzz since that hair is not strong enough to be pulled out (the emjoi does the same thing). But for me, that is just what I prefer. I want my face to look natural just less hairy -- and the broken-off fuzz makes it seem like I have the fuzz of a 5-year old. I only went for the waxing/threading because that seemed one way to get rid of the long fuzz as well as the darker hairs.<br /><br />As for the darker hairs, they are stronger and I think they were pulled out at the root because I cannot see themat all -- no broken off ones at all. If they had been broken off, I should feel them, because they are coarse -- and my skin is as smooth as the proverbial baby's bottom.<br /><br />And that brings me to the last result -- which was nothing! -- some redness (like a strong blush) that disappeared within 1/2 hour and NO PIMPLES! NO BUMPS AT ALL!!<br /><br />I can use this when I get out of the shower, and by the time I am ready for makeup, there is nothing to hide!<br /><br />So, forget other hair removers and try this one FIRST! Save yourself the money and pain I have gone through.

Then I maxed out my credit cards doing laser hair removal. I thought laser removal would be a permanent fix, but that's not true. I wasted all that money!   447. This product works amazingly well but requires some practice. The most important thing to know is that you must approach the hair from opposite the direction of growth. If the hair is growing toward the left, roll from the left to the right. My facial hair grows all different directions so I have to roll the thing every which way but it does eventually remove all of the hair. It is less time, less painful and less expensive than getting electrolysis. The next important thing is to roll slowly so the hair pulls out and does not snap off. You can feel the difference between a break and a pull out. Even when some hairs do break it is much better to have only a few grow back than having all of them grow back as when shaving. Initially I spent about ten minutes getting used to it and now I spend about one minute before bed every other night and have been delighted. The first use hurts like crazy as there are so many hairs to be pulled but from then on it is much less painful.
  448. I have very fair, extremely sensitive skin and was concerned the R.e.m. Spring Sprong wouldn't work for me. I'm so glad I ordered it: while it's a tad bit painful at first (but not any more than tweezing), I quickly got used to it, and it's so much easier and better than waxing, with no red skin or blemishes afterwards. It's fantastic for the upper lip, chin, and jawline to get those fine hairs that were impossible for me to tweeze before (and waxing left me with nasty red bumps for days). I had absolutely no problem figuring out how to work it: it even works great just rolling it flat (not much curving at all) in an upward motion. What an inexpensive, wonderful product!
  449. I had ordered this product an year ago and I am using it every two weeks since then. I am a big fan of threading and I always preferred threading over other methods of facial hair removal. R.E.M. Spring Sprong is the best substitute for traditional threading and is very handy. I use it to remove facial hair and it works really fine. If you regularly wax/thread your facial hair then there will be no problem of having rashes or tiny red spots over the face after using R.E.M. The only complaint that I have is that the handle is too small and its a little difficult to clean the hair off from the device. When I try to clean the hair off from the device, the spring gets loosened. I do have a little trick to keep the spring from not loosening up every time you clean it. Hold the spring straight and horizontally at the ends and twirl in opposite directions. Do this for a couple of times and it really helps in keeping the spring intact for further uses.

  458. This is an effective way to remove upper lip hair without the expense or pain of waxing and threading. The key is first to numb the area with an ice cube. Five to ten seconds does the trick. Yes, your pores will be closed which theoretically makes pulling the hair out harder, but I have found cold works much better than heat with this method. With the area numbed, I don't feel a thing and am able to quickly and thoroughly remove the hair above my lip. You will have to experiment with the spring at first to find the best twisting method, but once you do, this is a waste-free and affordable way to remove facial hair.

In time you won't even feel it but you will see the results - and without redness or skin blotches. I want another for travelling. thanks, Val

I only bend it to look like a smile, and roll. It is really that simple and will eliminate those unwanted hairs.   470. Just as for many reviewers, it took a few tries to figure out how to roll and twist for maximum hair removal - and then those unsightly chin hairs were gone! However - I'd like to make one slight correction to the manufacturer's description of the experience of using this product: They say - \\"Might feel a slight tingling sensation...\\" NOT!! Rolling this springy thing around one's chin and upper lip HURTS! It's pulling hairs out by the roots! I use it frequently - but I have to muster up my courage each time, knowing what's coming. So - great product, but NOT painless.
  471. I have super fine, very light colored hair on my upper lip and a bit on my cheeks next to my hairline. It's so fine/light that under artificial light, I can hardly see it and this makes tweezing next to impossible. I have had 2 tweezer-type facial epilators and neither one would really do much due to the hair being so fine.<br /><br />Years ago, I had an electric epilady that was much like this spring and it worked wonderfully. Unfortunately, they no longer make those and that's too bad because it was less painful and much faster than using this spring.<br /><br />However, I do really like this spring thing. The pro's are that you can use this virtually anywhere and I find that it's very easy to use as well. I'm so happy that I won't ever have to wax again! The waxing left my sensitive skin extremely reddened and it would actually take a day or two before my face returned to normal and it was a huge pain to apply the wax next to my hairline and not get any of it in my hair. I don't have that problem with the spring. Another nice thing is I can throw this in my purse and if I missed a spot, I can easily and quickly take care of it.<br /><br />The downside to this device is that since it is slower than an epilator, it's more painful (at least to me anyway) but if you just grit your teeth and keep at it, you get a little mini endorphin rush and long lasting results too. One other thing that's a bit of a downer is that since it takes both hands to use the spring, you can't pull your skin taut while using it on your upper cheek areas and even though I put my hair in a ponytail prior to using, I still have those \\"baby\\" tendrils that won't go back in the pony elastic and I'm not able to hold them out of the way while using the spring so have to use muliple hair clips to make sure I don't get that head hair tangled in the spring.<br /><br />Bottom line: If the fine people at Epilady decided to once again make the old style spring epilator, I'd definitely buy another but I'd also keep this spring for touch-ups when I'm away from home. The spring really does work, even if your facial hair is very fine.uch-ups when I'm away from home. The spring really does work, even if your facial hair is very fine.

  475. idk what to say. the item works, but it's really painful. i expected it however i thought it was one of those things like waxing where you get used to the pain. sometimes the hair gets uneven after using it, it's almost like shaving. some hairs get plucked and some just ripped parts of the hairs on the surface. it's too painful for me to use it properly maybe. i'm probably not using the item appropriately. i used it for a couple of months and then quit. the waxing method is more preferable to me. at least when it comes to the pain.
  476. This is a great product for removing unwanted chin hair. I will say if you plan to use this on your lip area, it will hurt.
  477. I have always used wax for my upper lip area. My skin & lips are very sensitive, and after waxing my lips for years with no real satisfaction I decided to try something else.<br />Here are a few reasons why I will never try another product for hair removal on my face again:<br />1) The Spring is AMAZING for super sensitive skin (waxing only irritates my skin & lips)<br />2) Quick & Easy (Wax takes a while to dry, and lets be honest- we all dread ripping it off) with this little device, I cut my &#34;hair removal time&#34; in half! Went from 30 mins (from application to being completely done) to 5 mins!!<br />3) Your skin gets used to it!! (If I do a few quick &#34;rolls&#34; before starting. My skin numbs itself & I can focus on where I need to remove the hair instead of the pain<br />4) NO mess!! (I have always hated the wax &#34;strings&#34; that you get after applying it- on the sink & my clothes. Not to mention those chunks of wax under your finger nails after pulling it off)<br />5)Cheaper & Lasts longer (I had my last spring for over a year and a half, and it worked great nearly the entire time!)<br />6) Your hair doesn't grow back thicker!!! Yeah, I know...pretty hard to believe, but its true! Ever since I started using this product, I noticed that my hair is not coming back thicker/harder to remove! It is not thinning, but hey its nice to know that its not as noticeable when it does grow back<br /><br />My Usage:<br />-Have been using this method for about 2 yrs and i'll never go back!<br />-By rolling the spring over your lip really quickly before getting more precise, you help numb your lips and the rest of the two minutes finishing up is a breeze for both pain & getting it taken care of in no time<br />-When I finish, I usually stretch the spring and let it snap back to get the excess hair out (you'd be amazed at how much hair it removes)<br />-I don't have to worry about getting wax at the store every few months, this little baby lasts for at LEAST a year!<br />-No messy wax getting on the sink, my clothes, or even the carpet (I have dropped it a time or two on the way from the microwave to the bathroom. And it doesn't come out of carpet!)<br />-Went from the 30 min- heat, apply, wait...wait....wait...RIP, clean up<br />TO:<br />-Run spring over lips quickly to numb & then finish off the rest in about 5 minutes or less<br />-I get cold sores and I have a TON less irritation after using this than I ever did with wax!<br />-It is a tad embarrassing, but yes I do get chin hairs & the spring works great on that area as well<br /><br />I originally stumbled on this product when I had a cold sore, and wanted to use something more gentle. I did some research, and saw a YouTube video on this (At first I thought OMG! That looks terrible- TRUST me, its not!) So it is a spring with two handles on each end. You will NEVER pinch your skin, so don't worry about that! When I run it over my lips to help numb; I hold the spring horizontal and then really quickly roll it down & out(away from you). You'll start by holding it with your thumb & your index finger. Your thumb will be closer to your face--- As you roll (down/back & out) your index finger will come closer to your face & thumb will move downward & away) I just keep doing this until I notice that it is not painful anymore and then begin with more detail. When you begin in more detail you can place the spring in multiple directions (not all of the hair &#34;lays&#34; the same way- think of this as &#34;going against the grain&#34; some hair is easier to remove at a different angle than the rest. I usually start at one corner of my mouth or &#34;st-ache&#34; area: Place the spring to &#34;follow&#34; your lips shape and then roll UP. You will know when you are at a good angle because you can feel it grabbing more hair (not in a painful way, but a &#34;hey its grabbing a lot&#34; kind of way) then I work toward the center. The middle usually does hurt a little more, so I typically go up to where my upper lips &#34;points&#34; are, and then Ill start at the other outer st-ache corner area on the opposite side of my mouth. Then when I've worked my way in, and its pretty much all numb, I will place the spring over my entire top lip lining and roll up to get the middle hairs. It is much easier to experiment & see what works best for you. But don't be intimidated, it is much faster, less messy, and less painful because you sort of ease the pain in which allows your skin to adjust instead of one big RIP and that tingly/irritated feeling after you wax.<br /><br />Good luck! Watch the youtube videos if you are still unsure of how to use this product, it helped me in the beginning!<br />Don't think that it is complicated, it is just hard to explain if I am not showing you how

  530. I bought this to help with my chin hairs. I have quite a lot of them and it's really embarrassing. Even though they are blonde, you can still see them in the sunlight. Years ago I made the mistake of shaving them off, and now more and more seem to be there every year. It takes forever to pluck one by one, so I was really hopeful when I saw this product.<br /><br />The first time I tried it, I thought i was following directions as I twisted the rods towards me and rolled along my chin. NOTHING happened. I put it away for a while and just today took it out again to give it a try. Turns out there is a little more than just rolling. You have to twist the springs while running them up along your skin, not rolling. Also I found you need to be going in the exact opposite direction of the hair growth. So for my chin, I had to angle it a bunch of different ways till it grabbed each hair. I also found it hurt less after a hot shower when my pores were more open.<br /><br />Wow...it really hurts. Especially when you get to that nice soft skin under your chin. BUT it works and that's what I was looking for. I even did my upper lip and got lots of tiny fine hairs off, too!   546. This baby works pretty good.....the other springs I tried did not
  547. I received it 2 days ago and it took me a minute to figure out how to use this tool. Really, it is not difficult at all. Put it on the area where you want to remove hair, bend, twist the 2 ends towards you at the same time as you move the spring in upward direction. its that simple. I have been threading by myself the old fashion way ( using threads around my fingers) for years and just could not take the threads cutting through my fingers and having to do so every other day (since the small hair would not pluck). This device is just amazing. it removes any little traces of hair (I did use a magnifying mirror). it took me a couple of minutes to get rid of upper lip and chin area. I am ordering two more, one for purse and the other for my travel bag. No bad reaction, no bruising nothing with this device. I do put a drop or two of my vitamin c serum in the area that is plucked. As far as pain goes, if you have threaded by yourself for years, you would say what I am saying - \\"It does not hurt - compared to the pain before\\". Arrived on time. No complain.
  548. I am loving this sprong. I did not know how to use it correctly at first, so I could not get any hairs up, but I kept trying until I had it right. Took about a full minute.<br /><br />And apparently I have way more hair on my upper lip than I previously thought (*blush*) because it got a lot more than I expected. This is much better than waxing because it isn't messy and with waxing you have to reapply and hope you get it all. Then there is the skin irritation and redness that comes with it.<br /><br />Plucking with tweezers is fine for obvious hairs, but it won't get the smaller ones like the sprong does. It does hurt quite a bit at first, but that is to be expected if you've ever had to remove hair the hard way. It almost feels like getting your hair snagged on something.<br /><br />It gets the job done though and it causes me no skin irritation which is something I've always hated because I felt like I had to take care of my upper lip when I had time to \\"recover\\" before being seen. With the spring I can just use it quickly and be done. I would recommend this product.<br /><br />I ordered this ground shipping on Oct. 14 and it arrived on Oct. 19 to TN.
  549. Using it for 3 months now. I just love it. I use to spend almost $30 per month to get threading done. Now it is easy and fun just twisting and turning. It does not hurt any more, first few times it does hurt but now it does not. It is so easy to carry and use it any time, any place. It is great.

  552. My two problems... 1. Although they're fine hairs, I have too many hairs above and below my lips and they grow RIGHT up to my lips. When I wax, if I so much as touch my lip with it and rip it off I end up with a bloody lip or a nice pink spot lining my lips... sores around your mouth = NOT SEXY! 2. I'm a redhead... very fair skin. When I wax, I have a dark pink goatee or beard for a good 6-8 hours after. I've even had a layer of skin ripped off and had a goatee for days. Embarrassing!!!! This little unit gets the itsy bitsy hairs right up next to the lip and doesn't leave a rash! And EVERYTHING gives me a rash! My first time using it was today. I sat watching TV and twisting that sucker and YOWZA you can feel it works... but you get use to it. My face is completely smooth as a baby's butt and NO pink spots! Took me appx 10 minutes! No burn feeling after. No itching. This is a ginger's best friend. :) SO happy!

  555. This is the best product I've used so far on facial hair-- so easy to use, very effective! I will now carry it around wherever I travel. Feels like \\"threading\\" but much gentler. I use once or twice a week-- Pulls off hair gently-- follow directions and twist as indicated. If you are not used to hair being pulled-- can be slightly painful but you will get used to it. Better if you have a 5x or 10x mirror. I even use this on my eyebrows-- though you need to be extra careful here as you could pull off hair in places where you don't want to.
  556. I have a lot of trouble with hair removal from my upper lip. With tweezing, it takes me about an hour and it looks like I still get only about half of the hairs... waxing is really expensive to do consistently, but always gives me the best results. I've had absolutely terrible luck with home waxing kits as the wax sticks to my skin more than to the paper. I've tried nair for the face, but it still only gets about half the hair and sits on the skin for 10 minutes, which is quite a while.<br /><br />I should mention too that I have very sensitive/fair skin- my skin is practically white, but my hair is very black, which is a terrible combination for facial hair. I am always on the lookout for new things that I can use to help me with this problem that is financially reasonable and decently easy/time efficient. Reading the reviews for this, I was excited, but hesitant. Nevertheless, I figured for less than $15 it was worth a shot. I mean, I pay close to that just getting my face waxed at a salon.<br /><br />I am so glad I tried this product! I followed the advice of one reviewer to turn clockwise with the right hand and counterclockwise with the left. I started near the lip and moved up to the nose. I used different widths of the bend- sometimes I held the spring straighter and others I tried it completely in an upside down u-shape.<br /><br />The pain was totally manageable. My eyes watered a bit, but it was about the same as plucking and less than waxing pain-wise. It was exponentially faster than plucking and got rid of all the hairs on my upper lip! I think for that, the pain was well worth it. I assume as I use it more frequently, the pain will decrease. I was pretty thorough, getting every single hair, and it only took about 3 minutes total time- way less than plucking does (and got sooo many more hairs).<br /><br />I followed the directions to clean my face after use and apply moisturizer and I didn't have any problems with breaking out. My skin was red for a few minutes after use, but it was honestly red for less time than after plucking or waxing. My skin is pretty sensitive though too, and I know that, so I was surprised that it wasn't more irritated for longer.<br /><br />I did get this primarily for upper lip, but I do have a few hairs on my chin area, so I tried it there too. I only have a couple every now and again, so plucking is still easier for those I think, but this worked well there too- getting the angles right was more difficult, but it seemed to work well once I did.<br /><br />I'd also like to comment on the hairs- I tried an epilator before that was designed for the face, but I found that it just broke off the hairs at the skin and didn't really pull them out. I can see all the hairs in the spring sprong AND I can see the little ends that show they were really pulled out and not just broken at the skin! Perfect! I am sooo glad I gave this product a try, and I plan to continue to use it for a long time to come!t was honestly red for less time than after plucking or waxing. My skin is pretty sensitive though too, and I know that, so I was surprised that it wasn't more irritated for longer. I did get this primarily for upper lip, but I do have a few hairs on my chin area, so I tried it there too. I only have a couple every now and again, so plucking is still easier for those I think, but this worked well there too- getting the angles right was more difficult, but it seemed to work well once I did. I'd also like to comment on the hairs- I tried an epilator before that was designed for the face, but I found that it just broke off the hairs at the skin and didn't really pull them out. I can see all the hairs in the spring sprong AND I can see the little ends that show they were really pulled out and not just broken at the skin! Perfect! I am sooo glad I gave this product a try, and I plan to continue to use it for a long time to come!

  572. As someone that is growing older (aren't we all....) and sprouting more and more little hairs in places where they don't belong (oh, aren't we all doing that as well?) I've been a waxer. But I have pretty sensitive skin, and waxing makes me break out, or even worse, gives me raw red patches on my face for days. Not attractive.<br /><br />So I was looking for an epilator and saw this. The price caught my eye. I like inexpensive. And since it would work for the area I need it, I decided to bite the bullet and order one.<br /><br />Hands down, it works. I did what a previous reviewer mentioned and turned my right hand clockwise left hand counter. Instant results. It is very painful, and that's coming from someone that doesn't think that waxing is painful. But I think that other reviewers are right--it will hurt less over time as you have to pull less hair. Took me less than 2 minutes to do my upper lip, and there was very little redness, and no swelling, after.<br /><br />I do recommend this for anyone that doesn't want to spend a lot of money on an epilator, or gets chemical burns from depilatories, or hates to wax.<br /><br />Edited to add: I wanted to add that I tried this on my chin today. I've always shaved my chin, and with hormone issues can sport quite the 5 o'clock shadow if I'm not careful. I shaved yesterday. Today I was able to pull a ton of hair from my chin. I did have to change the angle that I was using it (sometimes running it sideways instead of up and down), and have it bent more or less than I do on my upper lip. It's trial and error. I'm praying this works well enough that I do not have to shave anymore. It pulls those little hairs out all the way including the follicle. Ouch!

  591. The product arrived as advertised and I spent a good few minutes going over the instructions so I could make sure I used the R.E.M. Spring correctly. I tried it on the corner of my mouth first and after one or two false starts I got my hands coordinated and the hair came right out! Everything, including the peach fuzz, got caught in the spring. Some of the reviews I've read stated that the instructions were a little vague, but I was able to figure it out with a few passes. When holding the spring in a U-shape make sure both hands are place in the same manner (like holding a book), and then roll the ends of the spring towards your palms and then away. This causes the spring to move up and down catching the hair. My only trouble was when I attempted to do my chin. The angles make it more difficult to get the spring to catch so more passes were required. Overall, I found it less painful and more thorough than tweezing.
  592. This product is wonderful. I don't usually write reveiws but I have to say that this one does exactly what it says. It does hurt a little bit but if you are used to tweezing, it doesn't feel much different than that. What I love is that is gets every single hair, even ones you don't see. I am 44 years old and just recently noticed much more peachy fuzz on my top lip. I used mine about a week ago and I still do not see any growing back. I LOVE this product! No more time wasted with tweezing and no messy waxes or creams! It's fast and easy.

  596. I have PCOS, so there are coarse hairs growing on my neck. I've also got acne-prone skin and an aversion to strong chemicals. This looked like a great product that didn't need continuous maintenance or refills.<br /><br />It took me a few seconds to figure it out, and it didn't hurt as much as I expected. I'm used to tweezing the hairs individually. The thing is, the spring picked up all the vellus hairs and very few of the terminal ones. (Vellus hairs being the light, fine hairs like peach fuzz while the terminal/androgenic hairs are the coarser dark ones.) My skin is dark and although my vellus hairs are very long due to the PCOS, they're only visible up close. It was those scary, black hairs I wanted to yank out, but this product didn't help me with that.<br /><br />I really wish the spring worked for my purposes, but it wasn't able to pick up the thicker, more visible hairs. I also had a minor break out when I used it on my jawline. It seems to require multiple passes to have any effect on hairy folks like myself. I tried rolling it a few ways and after washing, but I still had to get the tweezer to pull out the remaining hairs.<br /><br />I think this will work well for people who have uniform hair types/lengths or people who want to pick up longish hairs that are fine to medium thickness. I personally wouldn't use it on the \\"mustache\\" area or another very sensitive place. The spring itself is well made, and it would be easy carry it in a purse or take it when you travel.<br /><br />It's too bad the REM Spring doesn't work for all hair types. I had to return it.
  597. I am ordering this product, knowing it will work well.   607. This thing yanks out hair. That's what it was designed for and it does it VERY WELL. You will probably cringe and tear up at some point. I still do. So if hair pulling makes you cry, well...don't get this. I use this on my chin because I have these unsightly short dark hairs that crop up every once in a while (the joys of having female hormones, yay). If they're shorter than 1/8&#34;, I use tweezers, but anything longer than that (probably because I have thick hair) gets grabbed. Really fine hair is difficult for me (user error?) and has to be longer before the spring is effective. This is basically for spot treatment. If you try to do a side of your face or something in one sitting, your skin will probably go numb from all the yanking and you'll be in tears--tweezing is not new for me, but I still tear up on the stubborn, deeply rooted hairs. And for heaven’s sake, don’t try this on any other part of your body! Honestly, this should go without saying, but I was curious to see if it would work on leg hair, so I tried a spot on my calf. It worked, but it was super painful. Never again.<br /><br />I've tried waxing and hair removal creams and because my hair is so dark and thick, neither method really works without serious side effects (like chemical burns). I’ve had to resort to shaving and this (it’s kinda ridiculous). This little sucker is only going to make whatever patch you're working on sting for a little bit and it might make the skin a little red because you just yanked out a bunch of hair. An ice cube on the skin will fix that easily. It's low tech, easy to use (there's only two ways to twist it, so if one way doesn't work, try the other way), still looks like new after the three years I've had it, and easy to clean. It works really well, but it’s not for weenies. ;P
  608. This package is so small I thought it had not come, but was in the box with a with a larger item. Guess what it really works! You bend it and then roll the little end pieces back and forth. You will know immediately when you make contact. It did nothing on my face but the hairs are sparse and very light. Oh the joy of aging, but this is a problem at any age I guess. Better than caustic hair removers, bleach, and I would imagine it will weaken the roots. Thanks.

  611. After trying every other device on the market (some expensive; some not), this little spring is, by far, the best -- works like a charm, takes half the time, and I don't have to do it everyday. No irritation afterwards.
  612. All the good reviews are true - this is such a simple product in design, and so effective. It's particularly useful for facial hair (EXCEPT EYEBROWS! DO NOT DO EYEBROWS!!!). Yes it hurts, but I found that applying a little bit of Benzocaine at the site of hair removal works really well. Regular use is also the way to go, as the finer hairs are not as painful to remove. Much safer than sugar wax on the face - which can sometimes pull off the top layer of skin.<br /><br />Update: Still hurts like heck, after several months of use. I find that using it after softening the hairs with a hot wet towel for 10-15 minutes also helps to minimizes the pain. If you plan on using this product before (or in preparation) of an event (e.g., wedding or formal event), do it a day or two before. If you have sensitive and light skin, you may have spots of reddening that usually takes several hours to disappear (for me at least).

  618. I wonder why so many people are unhappy with the R.E.M. spring. I have been using it for many months to happily (if sometimes painfully) rip out the hairs on my upper lip. I twist the spring against my skin so I feel it catch the hairs I want removed, adjust if necessary, and pull. Of course, it took some experimentation to learn the proper technique.<br /><br />I suspect many users' difficulty lies in following the official directions too closely. Those never did me any good, and the motion was exhausting to repeat as much as I needed to do it. The motions I use to catch hair in the spring are small, subtle, and effortless. It's more bending than twisting the item; gently separating the coils of the spring, applying it to the roots of the unwanted hair, closing the coils over them, and commencing a pulling and rolling motion. It is very quick. It helps to go against the growth direction of the offending hairs, and you might even want to ruffle them so they're standing up before you apply the spring.<br /><br />Voila: you may now elegantly decimate your moustache, or whatever. (Please do not get this thing anywhere near your eyebrows, though.)<br /><br />As for pain--yes, it does hurt if I've left the mini-moustache to grow for a few weeks. Take the spring to that kind of growth and, hell yeah, yanking out the hairs brings tears to the eyes. It is nothing like unbearable for me, though--which is really something, because I hate pain and am told I have a lower tolerance for it than other people do. Your experience may vary, of course.<br /><br />I find that it helps to shower, or at least wash my face, in very warm water if I'm having difficulty. It also helps a lot to apply a gentle, calming lotion or hydrosol to the area first, and throughout, if I'm removing serious overgrowth. I use the calendula and rose hydrosol (with aloe vera, etc.) from 100% Pure, or Avalon Organics' lemon hand & body lotion. Both calm irritated skin, and aid in healing things like those horrid little whiteheads that sometimes appear after depilatory treatments. (I get those rarely and minimally. Frequently washing and moisturizing the affected area with natural, high-quality products usually sees me clear in a couple hours.)<br /><br />And yo, the results? Perfect. Smooth. Much better than I got with burning, toxic bleaches. What troubled me most about the tufts that grow at the corners of my mouth is that they cast ugly shadows on my skin, looking ugly in photographs, and bleaching did not help. That problem is long behind me thanks to this little device!<br /><br />It may seem complicated, but I was trying to be thorough; the process takes me very little time, and I can do it during any moment of leisure in which my hands are free! It is tricksy to describe the technique, but I hope I was able to help someone. The R.E.M. spring can be an extremely valuable grooming tool if you let it.t sometimes appear after depilatory treatments. (I get those rarely and minimally. Frequently washing and moisturizing the affected area with natural, high-quality products usually sees me clear in a couple hours.) And yo, the results? Perfect. Smooth. Much better than I got with burning, toxic bleaches. What troubled me most about the tufts that grow at the corners of my mouth is that they cast ugly shadows on my skin, looking ugly in photographs, and bleaching did not help. That problem is long behind me thanks to this little device! It may seem complicated, but I was trying to be thorough; the process takes me very little time, and I can do it during any moment of leisure in which my hands are free! It is tricksy to describe the technique, but I hope I was able to help someone. The R.E.M. spring can be an extremely valuable grooming tool if you let it.

  627. Since I recently purchased the R.E.M Spring and the Epicare, this will be a review of both. As pretty much everyone else writing reviews about these products, I'd been fighting facial hair for years - mostly upper lip, and the thin hair on the sides of my face in front of the ears. And since I'm now in my 50s, these tiny little hairs were appearing on my chin, but I really couldn't see them well enough to get rid of them. I'd tried waxing, bleaching, depilatories, and shaving the upper lip. It was a constant battle keeping up with it. So I was about to spend what I saw as waaaay too much money on the No! No! Hair Removal System, when I ran into reviews of the R.E.M. Spring and the Epicare. I thought $15 or so for these products would be easier to take than nearly $300 for the No! No!, so I first purchased the R.E.M Spring. It did an absolutely great job removing all the hair I could and couldn't see. Yes, it was painful the first time - maybe the first couple of times - but it was doing a big job! It took a bit of practice figuring out exactly how to hold and twist it, and different positions work better for different parts of the face. It's probably different for everyone, depending on shape of face, direction of hair growth, etc., but with a little practice you'll find what works for you. People were saying they had two - one for home and one for their purse, so I bought the Epicare a couple of weeks later. I just wanted to see the difference. I would say they both work equally well. The R.E.M Spring seems to be made of nicer materials, and its spring is a bit smaller than that on the Epicare. The R.E.M Spring handles are made of metal, and the Epicare handles are a hard plastic. They both seem very durable, and I expect them to last a long time. I have become a little obsessed with using them, and use one of them every day. But there always seems to be some hair to remove, perhaps because it doesn't all grow in at the same time. All in all, these were both great purchases, do exactly what they claim, and I saved myself about $250 by not purchasing the product I had planned to purchase.were both great purchases, do exactly what they claim, and I saved myself about $250 by not purchasing the product I had planned to purchase.
  628. I received my spring about 2 hours ago and just by reading the reviews here, I learned how to use it properly and it really works! It sorta kinda feels like I'm getting shocked on my face a little bit but the pain isn't something you can't get over. I found that at first I had to bend the spring in a complete \\"U\\" shape and twist to get the hairs. After the longer hairs were gone, it seemed to have stopped working but I could still see some hairs in my magnifying mirror so I knew they were there. I referred back to these reviews and one of the first ones recommended that that the spring only be bent slightly while you twist it clockwise and counter clockwise at the same time. The spring didn't need to be opened that much to get those little hairs. This worked like a charm! I feel like a professional at this already. This beats putting that smelly hair removal cream on my upper lip anyday! My upper lip is hair free and I'm happy! I would definitely recommend this little tool to anyone wanting to get rid of those little unwanted face fuzzies.

  640. I have never written a review for a product, but for this one I decided to make an exception, simply because when used a little differently than instructed, it works amazing for me.<br /><br />Even though it is advertised that you must bend the spring, I actually just lay it flat on the piece of skin where I want to remove hair (in this case it is on the sides of my face). I find that when laid completely flat, it removes hair much better than when bent.<br /><br />Also, it is not necessary to use the handles themselves to roll the spring against the direction of the hair. I have gotten much better results when placing my fingers directly on the spring, and just rolling it upwards on my face. It is much easier to control the amount of pressure you place on the spring, and the direction you want it to go in as well.<br /><br />With these little tweaks, I really love how effective this product is; you may have to go over an area a couple times to ensure that the hair is removed, but it is worth it. No more waxing, thank goodness!

  671. I've used the spring for a month now, and I love it, but it took a while to get in the groove.<br /><br />I took it out of the box and got to work on my upper lip, which I have been bleaching lately (I'm in my 30's and have always gone back and forth between bleaching and waxing). It took me a while to figure out how it works. You need to roll the ends so that the open side of the flexed spring rolls closed, thus trapping and yanking out the hair. Let no one fool you...this HURTS!!! It is yanks out dozens of hairs by the roots at the same time. I wanted to quit and just WAX and get it over with, but I made myself finish the job. It worked great. No wax residue and the redness went away after an hour or two. If you can't handle it, just to a little bit each session,<br /><br />The next time I used it a few days later, it didn't hurt nearly as much, because there weren't as many hairs to pull. There were a few very short stragglers that I grabbed with my tweezers. After a month, my hairs must be used to getting pulled out, because it hurts far less.<br /><br />The great thing about this spring is that it is SO CONVENIENT. You can use it anywhere and it is not messy. After a few days, I decided to *try* to do my sideburns so that I could be free of bleach forever. I don't actually mind having fuzz on my jaw line, but since it's dark, I usually bleach. I knew it would hurt like crazy, so I decided just to tackle it a little bit every day. After a few days, I had cleared the whole area, and I'm not nearly as afraid to just run the spring over my jawline ever few days.<br /><br />Anyway, this spring has simplified my life. My hubby, who is admirably supportive with whatever I decide to do with facial hair, said he liked the results. Hope this works for you!!
  672. Works, there's a learning curve.
  673. This didn't really work for me. It was painful and I can't imagine using it in sensitive areas like the upper lip. Tweezers definitely work better for me. It also would take too long to do all the facial hair. It's like Chinese water torture to use this thing.
  674. i think you have to let the facial hair grow lots or you have to be really, really, really patient.......I didn't like it.
  675. This is the BEST product available for hair removal on your face! No more waxing or shaving! It's a miracle....easy to use and relativly painless! Love love love this.....have bought many for friends and family members!

  677. I ordered this March 11, 2013 and received on the 13th. Fast shipping and I am not a Prime member..yet. So to me that was a good sign :)<br /><br />I have sensitive skin but did not get any little red bumps. This could be due to the fact I always use Moisturizer both for cleaning and tinted for makeup use. I took this out and already knew the basis of using after reading all the reviews. Put it on my face in the U shape and started twisting the ends each going the opposite way of the other. Felt the usual sensation due to having hair pulled out. Yes, it does hurt but it's so quick it's nothing to deter from. On my upper lip it's better for me to let the spring be more of a frown vs a U. I do think for good results just like waxing or tweezing the longer the hair the better to grab.<br /><br />Was looking up the Oil of Olay Hair Remover when this came up. I really hate using chemicals, waxing, etc. I'm really glad I order this and took a chance. My face is smooth and there is no telltale sign that I have recently removed any hair.<br /><br />I will have to remember to put my hair all up as it will easily grab a stray long hair ;)<br /><br />For me the key steps for this to work is...<br /><br />1. Coarse hair will have to be longer just like with waxing/tweezing to get the desired results.<br />2. Go all different ways. Right, Left, Up, Down, etc.<br />3. Don't be afraid to veer from the U shape a bit. Sometimes having it a bit straighter works better.<br />4. For my Neck and Chin it was better for me to look up. This resulted in my neck being pulled tighter and this helped grabbed hairs. So find whatever position to work the spring better on not so straight areas.<br /><br />Good Luck :)
  678. I just received it today, and already I'm a pro! Well, not really, but I didn't find this too difficult to master. I was worried that I wouldn't figure it out, but it's just a coil spring that you roll around the areas of your face. In doing so, this thing rips off every little hair, but never pinches the skin. My method is just to roll between your fingers in a back and forth motion, and sideways, left to right. North south, east west. The quicker I go, the less pain and more hair I take off. I widen and narrow the U shape while doing so. It nips a bit in the beginning, but I was expecting this to be more painful than waxing, which it is not. I sat and watched a movie and rolled away, without wincing. And I am a big baby who can hardly handle a flu shot. I would have given 5 stars, but I'll agree that I think this is a little pricey. But for the money (and bruising) I'll save from not waxing, I'm glad I got this!
  679. This thing is so weird, but it is the best!! Uh, yes, it hurts! So does waxing, chemicals, plucking, etc. This thing is effective, and the results last a long time, 3 to 4 weeks for me. It is easy enough to do once you have it down, you can just sit in front of the TV and space it. I carry it around with me all the time. It really is the best solution out there for lip hair. FYI: It does say on the package don't try to use it on your eyebrows because your eyelashes will get caught in it. I read that and was like, yeah, if your reallllly dumb that would happen. I am a CPA after all. College grad and whatnot. First time I tried it on my eyebrows, it works its ninja magic and yes, my eyelashes got caught in it. I will never know how since my main priority was keeping them out of it, but it happened. So really don't try that.

  715. After reading the great review on how to use this hair remover, I tried with little success. Finally, I figured out that the problem was with the angle in which I was holding the Spring onto my face while twisting and rolling. I laid the Spring over my face and rolled it with my fingers atop the Spring. Viola! Success. Doing it this way is faster and easier than trying to twist the ends while moving the Spring. Just roll it over your face like you would roll dough on a surface to make it long and skinny. The Spring will grab every hair in the area where you roll it. I use fingers on both hands to roll it. By the way, I don't think it really hurts.

  728. I am 60, very fair and have always had a white blonde mustache and lots of stray chin hairs. Because it is all fair, I've not been a candidate for laser, etc. and have used tweezers. Recently I began to research epilady products, and stumbled on this device.<br /><br />It's easy use, and as another reviewer mentioned, the secret is going back and forth in several directions, while twisting the device with your hands in opposite directions (maintaining the more or less U shape recommended).<br /><br />This works very well: the discomfort is inconsequential, the results fantastic. Although one should definitely not use on eyebrows, I have used it in the peach fuzz like hair in between my eyebrows. Highly recommend this!
  729. I am SO excited about this little guy. I have fine blond peach fuzz on my upper lip and jawline so I don't know about how it would work on coarser hairs, but for me it's awesome. But now after that first time there's just a little 'prickly' feel. Not even uncomfortable. Also as a side note, my skin feels so smooooth and my makeup looks better too.<br /><br />To use it, I just held the two ends like the picture, formed a \\"u\\" with it, placed it below the hairs, and then spun or twisted my fingers and both ends at the same time back toward me as I moved up or across the hairs. I also worked across the fuzz in several directions. And as other reviewers have said, youtube has some great videos.<br /><br />I'm so grateful for all the reviews that helped me decide to try this awesome little Spring! though now I think I'm addicted to it :) Thank you guys! :))<br /><br />Jan 26, 2013: Follow up note on the \\"painless\\" part -- I've had this gizmo a few days now and I've discovered that if I use it every day there really IS no pain. Not even the prickly feel. So I guess the way to the no pain part is to keep up with the growth and not let it grow back in the first place. Honest -- there's no discomfort at all now.

  747. I have a lot of fine facial hair which makes my face look shady.I have been meaning to get the hair removed but was too scared that it would come back thicker.Anyway after doing some research I decided to go for it and got myself this spring.The first time I used it I dint take any precautions and touched my face all over coz it felt so smooth and nice.As a result I had the worst breakout of acne and pimples which took a good month to resolve.The marks are slowly disappearing.The next time I did it right.I followed one review written in the product reviews and washed my face clean and then epilated in the morning after bath.I put an ice pack after that and then I smeared my face with an antibiotic lotion and let it be that way the whole day.I dint touch it at all.I washed it before going to bed and then again applied the lotion and went to bed.I dint have any breakout after the second try. The pain is terrible though.It hurts real bad.So I take my own sweet time while at it.I do it in patches and stop when the pain is a bit too much to bear.It IS very painful.Hence the four stars.I will try it again next week and write my second review.

The R.E.M. Spring totally removes the hairs at the root! It is definitely a little painful, especially when removing hair along the upper lip and along the sides of the mouth but thus far, no ingrown hairs! Some chin hairs are more stubborn than others but multiple passes with the spring over the course of a few days usually gets those hairs out as well. I ordered the Hair Nix Facial Hair Growth Inhibitor weeks before ordering the R.E.M. Spring but using the two products together seems to work really well. Hairs grow at different rates of speed so the key to completely eradicating my problem will be consistency.
  752. The hard part is catching hairs that are in weird directions. I don't need to shave again as long as I keep using this spring. Shaving has left scars on my face and this is a cheap yet effective alternative. It leaves my face smooth and soft. I love this spring and i will keep buying replacements when lost (2 so far). The spring is \\"intended for women only\\" but that wont stop me.
  753. I wrote this review 20 min after receiving it! It sorta hurt at first, but it hurts LESS than tweezing did! after a min or two I got use to it and I am wondering why I even bleached to begin with. The redness is already gone unlike bleaching. I am SO impressed with this. I will never have to wax or tweeze or bleach again! I am going to save so much money!
  754. Doesnt work in all areas. If you have lot of hair, may work, but if you have that one tiny strand of hair, doesnt work, Doesnt seem that it takes from cuticle. Felt like it was shaving.<br /><br />Not sure how women are happy with this product.
  755. This is a great little gadget for removing hair on the upper lip, lower lip, and chin area. It is painful but the pain can be minimized if you moisturize the skin right before. I personally use Jojoba Oil on my face as a moisturizer and find it helps prevent irritation during the hair removal process. Just be sure to wipe off any excess oil/moisture from the skin so the spring can roll easily. Also be sure to turn the handles of the spring clockwise and counterclockwise as you move the spring in an up and down motion. You will need to widen the spring and move it sideways and such to get all the hair depending on the direction of the hair growth.<br />I tried it on other parts of my face but I found it to be too painful and not as effective. This is still a 5 star product in my book since it clears my upper lip and chin better than anything else.<br />It will hurt quite a bit the first time but if you keep at it every few days to keep the are free of hair, it will hurt less since you are only ripping a little bit of hair at that point verses the whole lip and chin.
  756. I can't understand why everyone loves it so much. It hurts like hell!! Maybe it gets better the more you do it, but it hurts too much to get to that point! Yes, it works, if you can tolerate ripping hair out of your face.
  757. I tried to use it and followed the instructions it gave me, and although I could feel it tugging at my hairs, nothing came off. Very disappointing...
  758. I found this tool harder to use then I thought it to be after reading reviews. It does hurt the first few times the most but instill found it difficult to pull all the hairs. I also experienced a couple small breakouts after use.
  759. We all know that Michael & co haven't particularly been cranking out new material in the last decade or two; but in the good old days, artists could at least fall back on existing album sales for a decent retirement. Every once in a while, when the itch to \\"live large\\" needs a scratch, hey, get the band back together and hit the road for another \\"greatest hits\\" tour, supporting another \\"greatest hits\\" album.<br /><br />Well, all was fine and good until digital media upset the Apple cart. Now with the kids sharing their Bit-Torrent files across the web in their iTunes programs, nobody's selling units anymore. And every pimply teen with an iPad has every greatest hits compilation you could ever make. Now the only time the gravy train rolls into the station for elderly and burned out artists is a new tour. Watching these codgers drag themselves across the stage at your local highly-flammible nightclub borders on the inhumane. Instead of treasuring the music of your childhood, now you have to see it fumbled out from the arthritic fingers of your idols of yesteryear.<br /><br />This is all to give a little background to the sad story of REM and their latest merchandising play. While branching out like this is an ingenious way to avoid leaving the house (getting prescription refills for your hypertension and high cholesterol is such a pain on tour! And forget about dealing with the insurance coverage), I have to say that branding a nose hair remover with the previously solid \\"Alternative\\" brand of REM might have been a mis-step. I am sure that the band members love the product (when you get old, hair comes out of your nose, ears and other unexpected holes) but maybe they could have held out for a classier product- I mean, even that rapist Vince guy has the Slap Chop.<br /><br />Anyway, I'm sure the REM Nose Hair Pulling Spring is great; but don't expect it to bring you back to the magic teen years like listening to \\"Document\\" does.
  760. I have struggled with trying to eliminate facial hair, as I cannot stand to discover that I missed a dark, coarse one after I come home and know that I was out and about like that! I am a fanatic about it. In fact, when I was hospitalized with a serious illness, I was driven mad with worry that I was sprouting it like wild weeds or something hahaha. As sick as I was, that was still worrying the heck out of me.<br /><br />Anyway, this device has freed up chunks of time from my grooming routine. It's so quick and so efficient. Over the upper lip does hurt a bit, but I suppose I am desensitized to the pain due to all the years of plucking the suckers out. My daughter found it quite painful, but I barely bat an eye -- so the pain level is an individual thing that can vary greatly.<br /><br />Pain aside, I don't see how anyone could argue against the fact that the thing really works. I consider my fifteen bucks well spent.

  774. Do not use this product! Does remove hair but peach fuzz and fine light hairs will grow back as very thick hair so when you could hardly see the hair before, you are stuck with a man`s beard after. Do not recommend at all!

  776. Just got this in the mail and used it today. AH-FREAKIN-MAZING! Seriously. I'm tempted to buy 5 more just in case I lose it and they stop making it.<br /><br />I'm part Italian, but instead of having skin that tans easily in the summer, I was blessed with hair... lots and lots of hair. I mean, hair on my legs, hair on my stomach, hair on my arms and yes, hair on my face. I've tried bleaching, shaving, tweezing, waxing and asking nicely for the hair to depart from my upper lip, but alas, I remained unsatisfied. So needless to say, when I learned about this spring thing I was kind of excited. I read all of the reviews and decided to give it a try. I'M SO GLAD I DID!<br /><br />It definitely hurts, I mean, obviously- you're pulling hair out of your face. For me, it didn't hurt so much on my chin, but the upper lip and the sides/cheeks are a bit rough at the start. But I have a pretty high tolerance for pain, especially if it promises a smoother upper lip. The pain doesn't last long though. And I don't know the whole science behind it but after you do it a few times- it doesn't hurt so bad. Besides, it was all over in less than 5 minutes (probably more like 3).<br /><br />So I started out with a pretty hairy stash (I let it go a bit knowing this thing was coming in the mail... good thing I didn't have to go anywhere, haha!) and now I've got nothing under the nose. I also did my chin- things are a lot better off there too. After I was done I still had a few short thick hairs left, but I'm willing to tweeze those out if this spring thing will do the rest. On that same note- there were a few stragglers after I was finished, but I just plucked those out- no big deal After all that, I started on my cheeks, but I was sort of tired by then, so I gave up. It definitely works though. And I am SO EXCITED about my upper lip.<br /><br />So, I'm serious people- ladies- TRY THIS! I know what it's like- the constant battle of the man hair. It makes you feel so not feminine. So I say it again - TRY THIS THING!
  777. I may have missed it, but most reviews are from women. As a guy, I have very thick facial hair, very dark, and densely populated. I have a 5pm shadow by noon. That said, a number of years ago, I had most of my facial hair lasered off with reasonable results - my skin was sensitive to shaving, which made it bothersome and results not ideal. Except for the chin (corner of mouth to corner of mouth area), most of the hair is gone or very fine. i.e. from 10 thick hairs per 2mm square area, to 10 fine ones per sq inch. My chin, while some areas were light, just never really responded to the laser treatment. So you know what I'm starting with.<br /><br />Does it hurt....YES. About the same as tweezing (which I hate, given the number required for visable results with the pain), but for the same amount of pain, you get many many more hairs. The first time is a.....lets just call it an experience. I found it hurts less in the evening....don't know why, so one might try a different time of day.<br /><br />Most people have reasonable directions on use, and suggest reading those. i.e. bend the thing, twirl the correct way, and move up your face.....which given which way the hair grows, you might have to change directions. If the hair is not laying in an ideal direction, it may pull the hair, but not actually remove it....basically, the pain without the result. BTW, I have not decided if tightening the skin surface is better or not.<br /><br />For the density of my facial hair, the spring looks like something wrapped around an axle, but pulling 20-30+ hairs at a single twist is pretty good. I can't do the zippy thing they show in videos and desc of twisting in and out as you move up the face. I think in part, the hairs are thick and many of them in a small area. Though, once thinned out, it goes much better - hairs kinda flick around btw, the spring twangs when I use it in dense areas.<br /><br />The first time I used it, after some painful experimentation, I cleared a 1 in sq area in a rather dense area on the point of my chin, with some blood, as it is ripping the hairs out. Took only a few minutes, but I had had enough for that go around....I was very pleased with the results. When I did get around to a second round...given how I feel afterwards, I'm calling them rounds...anyway, the second round resulted in at least 66% of my chin hair being removed - say, a 4 sq inch area. My skin is sensitive for about 24hrs after, so maybe in a week I will do round 3. At which time I would expect to only have maint at that point.<br /><br />As for the sides of my face, and under my chin, the hairs run in all directions, so some experimentation will be needed to work this - something to consider after my chin. The hairs are also finer there from the laser removal.<br /><br />Hair length doesn't seem to matter. I had stubble that I could just barely tweez(one days growth), and I also let it grow out for a few days. Similar results I think, though, the longer hair does allow one to see which way the hairs are growing.<br /><br />For those that do not know, hair folicals have growth period, followed by a holding period (if i remember correctly), followed by release, then a dormant period. What this all means, is that you will see hairs grow back in an area recently mowed as the dormant folicals that missed your deforestation begin to grow again.red a 1 in sq area in a rather dense area on the point of my chin, with some blood, as it is ripping the hairs out. Took only a few minutes, but I had had enough for that go around....I was very pleased with the results. When I did get around to a second round...given how I feel afterwards, I'm calling them rounds...anyway, the second round resulted in at least 66% of my chin hair being removed - say, a 4 sq inch area. My skin is sensitive for about 24hrs after, so maybe in a week I will do round 3. At which time I would expect to only have maint at that point.<br /><br />As for the sides of my face, and under my chin, the hairs run in all directions, so some experimentation will be needed to work this - something to consider after my chin. The hairs are also finer there from the laser removal.<br /><br />Hair length doesn't seem to matter. I had stubble that I could just barely tweez(one days growth), and I also let it grow out for a few days. Similar results I think, though, the longer hair does allow one to see which way the hairs are growing.<br /><br />For those that do not know, hair folicals have growth period, followed by a holding period (if i remember correctly), followed by release, then a dormant period. What this all means, is that you will see hairs grow back in an area recently mowed as the dormant folicals that missed your deforestation begin to grow again.

  797. Purchased on of these. Works great on my mostly peach fuzz. I do however, have a warning. After several months of using this product, I started to experience pain and stiffness in the saddle joint (muscles around where the hand and thumb meet). For a while, it only bothered me when I was driving so thought it was maybe the way I was holding the steering wheel. Finally figured out it was the twisting motion. Discuss this with the chiropractor and he confirmed that the twisting motion torks (muscles moving in opposite directions) the muscles of the saddle joint. Really painful. Too painful to be adjusted. Quit using it. Be careful with this product.

  839. If you've ever attempted to tweeze hair around your mouth and chin, then you know exactly what this contraption feels like. At first, until you get the hang of it, you will likely tell yourself that it's just too painful and decide to never use it again. But then you might reconsider because you don't want to be a wimp or because you don't want to throw your money down the drain. We are not quite out of the throws of the recession and unemployment rates are still high, the cost of things is higher still.<br /><br />After trying, I recommend watching a few YouTube testimonials and the review from Becky Gardens. She is honest and shows the correct way to maneuver the device.<br /><br />Tweezing my brows is nothing because I've been doing it for years. I remember though, how painful it was at first. Over time, it will become less so. I think in about a month with regular use, this will not hurt and be only discomfort. In about 2 months, I'll probably be down to no pain.<br /><br />I never tried using baby orajel or the like myself, but I read this years ago that it would help those starting out with tweezing hair removal methods. I think it would probably work in this instance as well.<br /><br />Using this on the hair around my mouth was quick and easy. I'm still working on the chin hairs, as it requires trying different positions to get those hairs if you have many and not just 1 0r 2.<br /><br />I highly recommend not trying to remove it all at once. Rome wasn't built in a day and you'll likely be more successful taking your time by spreading it out, a little every day or every other day. Once you get the hang of it (took me 20 minutes), as painful as it is, you may be tempted to finish the job. I say resist the urge if you can because if you overdo it, you may never pick up the device again, whereas if you do it little by little, you will love the results so much you'll stick with it and with each session, the sensation of pain really does go away.<br/><br />I also recommend keeping up with it, doing maintenance while the hairs are very short and barely visible. The longer the hair, the more pain.

Sometimes I want to get it out before it comes out, but you can't do that because that's how marks can form. I don't know if it's something scientific, but it seems like direct tweezing causes hairs to grow back faster stronger and thicker. If you're tired of tweezers, this is worth a try.

  869. Like my title says, this product works. It's basically a do-it-yourself threading kit. A normal threading session at the salon would take about 15 minutes to get all my hair removed. Using this product, I was done in about 5 minutes.<br /><br />To use it, at first I coiled it up tight and then \\"let go\\" so it could capture the hair. Once I realized that I just had to spin it with each hand going a different a direction, I started doing it that way. It's very, very quick.<br /><br />I don't usually rush to write a review on this site, but for a product that makes me happy (threading cost me $20/visit, this thing cost about $15 and I can use it over and over), I will jump on amazon and write a good review as soon as I use it.<br /><br />One thing I would suggest to the new user - get your facial hair threaded once and watch what the technician does.   871. The only things I've ever waxed were my eyebrows and bikini line--and those were only once each. And they hurt like hell. After spotting numerous black hairs on my face (of mostly blonde hair) in my late-20s, I got tired of randomly plucking and said \\"to hell with it\\". I'll break it down in points, because, well, my thoughts happen like this in my head, too.<br /><br />1. Does it hurt? Given that my waxing experiences are pretty much non-existent, I'll make this simple. YES! You can't rip hair out from the roots (especially fine hair on sensitive areas of the face) without pain. Now, if you've waxed before, and more than my meager attempts, it may not be so bad. Do you get used to it? Yes, but it takes time. The upper lip was far more painful. Chin and forehead, not so much.<br /><br />2. Where can I use it? I did use it around my eyebrows, but not on the brow itself. The middle area where people tend to get unibrows was an easy area to clean up. It can be used anywhere on the face, but won't pick up extremely fine baby hairs, as many have mentioned.<br /><br />3. Breaking out. You are rubbing a metal surface on your face, it will pick up oil and dirt from other areas, so you may be more prone to breaking out. To avoid this, wash the face before or after, and also use a cotton ball of rubbing alcohol on the spring after (or something to clean it).<br /><br />4. Ease of use. It takes 30 seconds to get use to it. You don't have to bend it, it just makes it easier for certain areas as there is less surface area. Roll your fingers in the same direction. If it hurts and you want to chicken out before ripping your hairs out, roll them in the opposite direction (for example, if turning away from your face pulls, turn toward your face to release). Pull your skin taut to prevent excessive tugging on the skin.<br /><br />5. After effects? I only started using it, so I'll let you know, but I expect the hair will stay gone for days-weeks and will return asit always does. *sigh* I also expect it may eventually come in finer over time.<br /><br />Overall, I'd say that this little bugger is a good investment if you can deal with a little pain for she sake of beauty/vanity.

You'll know the difference between when it's working, and when it's not. Overall, I'd recommend it!

  916. I bought this product only a month ago (it seems like so much longer because I have grown to love and rely on it so much!) and it has really changed my life! That may sound silly or like an exaggeration but as a fair skinned young woman who has always had dark hair above my lip I have felt the pain and embarrassment of having facial hair as a female. I have been on my way to class or work or a date even in my car, looked up in the mirror and with the sunlight seen all of the hairs I missed plucking my upper lip. This product has completely changed that! I have some dark hairs and also a lot of peach fuzz usually as my \\"mustache\\" and this completely takes care of that in an instant! You don't need a mirror and once you get the hang of it you can do it so fast and in any position- I usually do it in bed every night before going to sleep as my hair grows pretty fast and this deals with them quick. I have been tweezing the upper lip area for maybe 5-6 years (I am 21 now) and my upper lip area is so used to the hair tugging so I feel virtually no pain using this product. I have used it on my whole face (which I also love to get an extra smooth face as it greatly reduces my peace fuzz) and the only spots that truly hurt me are my chin area directly under my lower lip and my sideburn-ish area near my ears (the peach fuzz is extra dense there so I think that makes it hurt more). I never have to worry about my 5 o'clock shadow or missed hairs or people noticing the dark hairs and peach fuzz in good lighting and now I am so much more confident. I wish I had this in my teenage years as it would have saved me a lot of heartbreaking embarrassment that facial hair gave me. I can't wait to use this product and I actually got a little addicted to the smooth feeling. I definitely recommend it, I hope this type of product is on the market for the longterm because it is incredible and I know I will be buying more!

  921. A few days ago I went a searching on Amazon for something to help with facial hair removal and came up with this product. Reading about it and then reading the reviews, I felt pretty sure this would be a good investment. I was wrong - it was a GREAT investment!<br /><br />I am so pleased I cannot even begin to express myself. Yes, there is a slight learning curve in terms of how to use it. To be honest, after reading some of the reviews (take it like this, do it this way, etc.), I thought it was going to be really difficult to use. Nope, not at all! First let me say this even if it is obvious! Keep your head hair out of the way! I'm sure you can figure out how I learned that one! Next, play with it! Don't make it too serious of an event. You will quickly figure out how it works and then refine your skills. As far as pain is concerned, I'm sure it is all relative and quite subjective. To be honest, it doesn't hurt me. Yes, it tingles a bit once I'm done but it doesn't hurt. Everyone is different. One little secret - keep it moving faster rather than slower. It is sort of like removing a band-aid in that respect - the slower you go, the more uncomfortable it will be!<br /><br />As for the results - fantabulous! It didn't take all that long and my whole face feels smooth as a baby's bottom! All the tweezing in the world will never accomplish that! Are there other effective ways to remove facial hair? Probably but do any of them only cost $12.99 for multiple uses? Not that I'm aware of!<br /><br />So don't be afraid of this little sucker! The learning curve really is relatively small, especially if you play at it, and the discomfort is minimal and doesn't last long. How I wished I had found this 15 years ago before all the electrolysis and the emotional pain I went through as a result of my ever increasing facial hair! Yep, I'm one happy camper now!
