Using it on my upper lip is less painless than waxing. It is more subtle and does NOT pull on the skin. It only rips out the hairs. At times, it almost felt rewarding to roll the spring up and down because I was so confident it was working. And it did. It got rid of all the prominent hair on my upper lip (side note here: when I wax my upper lip, it removes every bit of hair and it actually makes me look weird... like a naked mole rat or something. This product makes my skin there look natural. The product definitely provides for hairless skin, but idk.. it just looks and feels more of a subtle change than the drastic red hairless skin you get from waxing). My skin was red for about 20 minutes; I just put a little vitamin E oil on a cotton ball and patted it on my upper lip right after using the spring. That's it. So simple and so happy! However, if you do not use this product with swift hand movements, I can see how it might not be effective and possibly more painful.   960. At first, I was not going to review this product because there were already so many truthful, positive reviews; now I know firsthand that those who say the spring works well are correct! However, there is one warning I feel the need to share. The company claims that the spring will not cause irritation, but if you have very sensitive skin like I do, it DEFINITELY will. My face was red after using it. I had peach fuzz all over my face that was noticeably longer than most people's, but due to my sensitive skin I was not willing to wax (or shave, for obvious reasons). So, since I had a large area to remove hair from, my skin was very irritated by the time I was through. It definitely smarts a lot, but it's bearable enough to finish the task. Anyways, the redness went away by the next day, and I was so happy with the results! I had a smooth, hairless face and felt confident, no longer conscious of walking into bright light that illuminates blonde hairs. The spring is a DREAM in this sense. However, the trouble came a few days later when I started breaking out. I have acne-prone skin and even though I cleaned the spring before I used it, with my pores all being open after the hairs were ripped out, I had TONS of tiny pimples all over my face. Days after that, I even had a few large ones as well. My face was a mess! Now that the breakout is done and gone, I have to say I still do not regret using the spring, because it DID do a very good job of tweezing out all the long vellus hairs on my face, chin and neck. The spring grabs even the tiniest of hairs--you just might have to experiment to find the right angle to grab them. Overall, I would DEFINITElY recommend the R.E.M. Spring.

I presume that's because it's grabbing more little peach fuzz over a larger surface area. Threading on the other hand is more controlled. More pain and less irritation sounds paradoxical, but that's the case for me.<br /><br />It turns out to be something that I won't be likely to use. But, if you can grin and bear it, I'm sure you'll find this more helpful than waxing and the like at home.<br /><br />I picked this one because it was cheaper, and I just wanted to test the concept. Maybe at some point in the future I'll try a more expensive version to see if it hurts any less.<br /><br />It took me a little while to figure out how to use it, and in the process my fingers got pretty tired. If you have larger hands or arthritis, this might be sort of annoying to use. The spring is pretty short, yet you have to keep it bent and twist the ends when you use it. Cumbersome and painful, but it's still pretty effective.
  971. This is my favorite way to remove upper lip hair. My skin is too sensitive to bleach, I dislike waxing, and tweezing the individual hairs is too time consuming. Before this product, I would lightly razor the area...with my boyfriend's razor. This is exactly what I needed! It's easy to use and of a simple concept, is fast and effective at hair removal, AND extremely cost effective in the long run. My only qualm is since you are pulling out hairs from a sensitive area, it can be kind of painful. I recommend icing the area beforehand. Otherwise, it's over quickly and does a good job so that you don't have to use it all that often.<br /><br />p.s. It seems kind of fragile to me...if you have a child rooting through your makeup bag or bathroom drawers, take care that they don't play with it and stretch out the coil or you may have to order a new one
  972. I read the great reviews, yet kept putting off the purchase. I can't tell you how pleased I am now that I finally bought it. At least this way you aren't risking a chemical reaction or burn and having an embarrassingly reddened upper lip for a few days while the skin heals.<br /><br />In order to use this, do note that you have to be twisting your fingers in opposite directions - one clockwise, one counterclockwise, to tighten the spring. Once you get the hang of it, it's easy and a great, quick way to take care of those embarrassing, pesky hairs!

  981. It pulls the hair out above your upper lip when it's angled right, and when you're tensing your upper lip tight against your teeth. However, when you move to your chin, where you don't have as hard a surface as teeth underneath, to tense your skin against, it becomes more laborious, and time consuming, producing little results. It worsens when you move to other facial areas that don't have a hard area (like teeth) underneath to provide a hard base to tense the skin on. It might be ok for young people who have really tight skin. But, for those of us with looser skin, this product is a waste of time, and does little. Bottom line: You need to be able to tense your skin (stretch it tight, distorting your face) tightly against a hard surface to achieve results. If you can stretch your skin to a very tight point and hold it there, this product might be good for you. I found out the hard way that the only spot it was good for, for me, was my upper lip.

I was spending 30 minutes a day plucking the little hairs that would magically appear over night. I decided to go with this product. I figured for the small price what do I have to lose.   998. I didn't have a hard time getting used to the tool, but I had help from the previous reviewers. I tried a couple times twirling in different ways, and I got the hang of it quickly. If you are getting frustrated that you can't get all the hairs, make sure that you are moving the spring in the opposite direction of the hair growth. This is important. You will not be able to capture as many if you are not angling to spring correctly. I wanted to be able to use it in my eyebrow area, but unfortunately, I don't think I can angle it correctly to do that. Overall - a great tool for your upper lip area.

  1011. I LOVE this product. I have tried everything in the past from smelly chemicals, bleaching, waxing, threading, etc, and nothing seems to work entirely. Now, keep in mind, this product is not a miracle product that just poofs your unwanted hair away. You have to be ballsy enough to take the plunge and put it against your face and let it rip the hair out. Did that scare you?<br />When I purchased this product I was so scared to use it because of all the comments that this is too painful. So I waited, and waited, and waited. One night I was bored and I attempted to use it. Yep, it hurt. I started with my upper lip which I have waxed before. This spring didn't hurt more than waxing, but it hurts in a different way. With waxing, your skin gets warm and you can pull the hair out with one quick swipe. With this spring, it took a while for me to get the hang of it so I could feel each tiny hair being pulled out. But I don't care. The truth is... it was pulling each tiny hair out! When I was finished with my upper lip, the spring had pulled out both tiny fuzzy hairs, and the larger thicker hairs. The best part is that there was no shadow on my skin or irritation as bad as I get from using chemicals. Also, after a couple minutes of using this, my skin became almost numb and it was much easier to use. It's just those first few pulls that don't feel too good.<br />A few days later I tried this on my cheeks. My cheeks aren't too hairy but have tiny little peach fuzz that starts fairly close to my sideburns. I figured, why not? This did great on my upper lip. WOW. My skin looks so soft and smooth after using this on my cheeks.<br />Right now I use this about once a week and that's enough for upkeep. If I did it more frequently it probably wouldn't hurt as much each time because my skin would be more adapted to using this.<br />I also took advice I read in some other comments - I wash my face really well and use a toner before using the spring. I also drown the spring in rubbing alcohol before and after using it. I've found if I do this I don't break out nearly as much.

  1026. The whole inverted U thing? While rolling and pushing up and down?<br /><br />No, this seriously doesn't work. For one thing, it's wide open when it's at this position meaning it doesn't pull much of anything. I also found it way too awkward to use this way. What seemed to work was expanding and collapsed (basically squeezing hairs) and rolling. This was at a straight line rather than a U, and I can try places that are supposedly off limits like the eyebrows.<br /><br />Less painful and time-consuming than tweezing (which I won't even try), but not very effective, and the learning curb is too steep. I'm sticking with my electric razor.<br /><br />If you have thin women's hair, this may be different. But after trying the same patch I only got a few hairs plucked out with a Norelco electric razor. Within five minutes, I got more hairs close enough for my liking with almost no pain. I'll try this again when my neck hairs grow out again, but this seems like I wasted money.

  1028. I have gone through lots of different hair removal products - creams, wax, sugar, epilators. All of them are bothersome in some way (creams kill my skin, wax is a pain and messy, sugar doesn't always work, epilators are slow). So why not try the REM spring?! Yep, in some areas, like the outer edges of my mouth. OUCH. (the lady smiling in the photo must be on drugs) Other areas it does not really hurt at all. The key is to go quickly and keep your skin taut. It only takes a few minutes to get the hang of it the first time you use it, after that it's a piece of cake. Like any hair removal product that takes hair out at the root, you will have a bit of redness after you use it, but it clears up quickly, and there's no residue from wax, no drying out from creams.<br /><br />This is the simplest and easiest solution for facial hair removal out there.

  1030. Purchased 2, one for a gift. It is good alternative to plucking, saves a lot of time and virtually pain free.
  1031. Just got the R.E.M. to day and used it right away. I have peach fuzz and a little mustache plus a few stray coarse hairs on my face. The R.E.M. got rid of the peach fuzz and the mustache hairs but was hit and miss on the coarse hairs, but I have to really pull at those with my tweezers sometimes (thankfully there are only a very few of them). Once I got used to the hand motion needed to make The R.E.M. work it was very simple and easy to remove hair. I bent the R.E.M. in a gentle inverted U shape and moved it up and down my skin at the same time rolling the handles in and out (left hand going counter clockwise and the right going clockwise on the out motion and the reverse on the in motion). After I got the rhythm going it didn't take long to do my entire face. I get my eyebrows threaded and on occasion get my upper lip and face threaded also. While I will continue to have my eyebrows professionally done I will now do my face and upper lip at home and save myself 25.00 a pop. The R.E.M. has already paid for itself! As for the discomfort, as I said earlier I get threaded and it feels the same. The face, tingling and the upper lip, all I will say is OUCH! I was flirting with the idea of getting a NONO but the price (250+) and the reviews (mostly 1 star on every site it is sold) made me decide to try the R.E.M. and I am very glad I did.

  1034. I am a frequent consumer of hair removal products. I actually was reading over a review I wrote on here in 2010 for a wax hair remover I have used relatively happily for years and have come to prefer for its cost, comfort and general effectiveness over other even professional methods such as laser and electrolysis. This little item, I think rivals if not surpasses the ease of use and practicality, not to mention the cost, of the wax strips and I hope to continue to learn to use the REM Spring as effectively as possible. It is not as you might imagine as easy as this smiling face makes it look, and especially on the upper lip! If you have a lot of hair, like me, you are never going to find a product that will eliminate all the unwanted hair, but I think with continued practice, I can eliminate a good amount of it with this, and then wax the rest. It is also practical to use because I actually keep it in my car and use it while stopped at a traffic light or in the parking lot before going into work!
  1035. I recently had my face threaded not for the first time but after a long time, and it was awesome. So I bought this based on the good reviews since I was hoping to find something that would spare me the expense and hassle of getting to the salon. It didn't have to be perfect, just close. This came close, but not close enough.<br /><br />The biggest problem with the REM spring is most of the time instead of pulling out the hairs, it just breaks them off. So while your skin may feel smooth, you're left with a dark root - ie a five o'clock shadow. A part of this is because the spring is wiggly (duh, it's a spring) and doesn't really allow for a firm enough grip for the user nor is it stable enough to roll over and grip the hair and pull it out from the root. It grabs what it grabs and moves one. The equivalent of shaving with a razor really.<br /><br />It also misses hairs, both fine and coarse. Seems to work best where hairs are grouped together. If you're someone one prone to random stray hairs, forget it. I went over one area dozens of times and it still didn't get one particular hair.<br /><br />In the end, my face felt smooth (temporarily) but in some areas didn't really look it (fair skin, dark hair). In at least one area, it felt smooth after I used the REM Sping, but a couple of hours later, I could feel them growing back in. (Yes, my hair goes very quickly.) After threading, I lasted 4 days before I could feel them growing back in. Over a week before I could see anything.<br /><br />Disappointing. Will work in a pinch, but not a replacement for better methods.<br /><br />BTW, yes it's somewhat painful, but it's no worse than being plucked, threaded or waxed.
  1036. I only write product reviews if I really has something to say. What this means is that I'm only going to write something if I absolutely hated the product or I absolutely loved the product. This is a definite &#34;LOVED IT&#34; product!!<br /><br />This product is ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!!!! I am a woman who has tried EVERYTHING (tweezing, threading, shaving, waxing, Nad's and Nair) to get rid of the fine (but long) dark hair on my face. I was about to purchase the No! No! and read several reviews which frightened me... and then I was directed to the R.E.M. Spring. Review after review after review spouting nothing but fantastic comments. It was $5. I was willing to lose $5 if it didn't work. So I bought it. Let me tell you, this is the best money (of ANY amount) that I have ever spent. The product is brilliant.<br /><br />It definitely takes a little trial and error, but after about 2-3 days you will be an absolute expert. As with many of the other reviewers, I will also say that it is not painless. The first time is the absolute worst, but it gets better from there. I use it daily (just to keep completely smooth). No redness, no chemical burns, no breakouts from products, no awful smells, no sensitivity. Try it and I swear you'll think it's bumped sliced bread right out of its coveted &#34;Best Invention&#34; spot.
  1037. I used this product several times to remove the hair around my chin area and lip. The hair grew back the same thickness and consistency (contrary to popular beliefs).<br /><br />Also, the hair around my chin grew back the same speed (give or take 1-2 weeks) as shaving. I rather shave twice a month than use this painful product once a month.<br /><br />As for the lip area, I find that an inexpensive eyebrow razor works extremely well over this product.<br /><br />I wouldn't mind using this product if it kept the hair from growing back longer. Since it didn't, it wasn't worth the time or pain to me.

  1050. Soooo I'm Italian and hairy. Enough said. This is a cool appliance - I like it because you don't have to use hot wax and risk damaging your skin. It just grabs on to your hairs. It kind of hurts but it's more of a stinging and to be honest I've felt worse. You kind of have to go over the same spot a few times and I can see how it would take a while for people with a ton of hair. But it's cheap, reusable and easy.<br /><br />Oh and the people who said it made them break out - think of it like this: you are pulling hairs out and leaving a small hole, which is a potential space for dirt and bacteria. So before you use this device, wash it and your face. After you use, just wash your face and use an astringent to close the pores. It's just a matter of keeping your skin really clean.

  1066. If you find yourself plucking or waxing to get rid of unwanted hair, this is definitely your product. First, minor but true, you don't get the hand cramps you do using a tweezers. Second, this catches multiple hairs in one swoop, and you don't need to be looking in a mirror to use it. It saves hassle, time, and you can use it anywhere you are (vs sitting in front of a mirror or holding one).<br /><br />Yes, it takes a bit of experimenting to get the right angles and get the most out of it, but you'll figure it out, it's not rocket science. The key trick is to rotate the handles or the spring to 'catch' or 'grab' hairs right off the skin. Often simply rolling it at an angle along the skin will grab hairs, but you'll learn quickly how to get the most out of it.<br /><br />Worth the money!
  1067. I am a 50 year old woman going through &#34;the change&#34; and we all know that means more facial hair! Up a couple of months ago, I was bleaching, but I could still notice the significant &#34;mustache&#34; I have tried waxing over the years and breakouts were the result. Also creme hair removal doesn't last at all. I am olive-tone skinned and have pigment issues so I have not and will not try laser due to possibility of irreparable pigment damage in such an obvious place.<br /><br />Very satisfied with the results. Best product for lip hair removal I have used. Warning.... the first time I used this product it took some practice and second, it took some getting used to the pinching of hair pulling (not like waxing), especially the first time when you have the most dense amount of hair to remove. Thicker hairs are more difficult to grab than thinner ones as will the ones at the lip. Some tweezing will be required for the occasional thick hair and strays. BUT, honestly, maintenance is like plucking eyebrows but faster. Oh, and I recommend you use this at night before bed as with waxing, there may be some associated redness (normal) that may take some time to abate.<br /><br />The info below is at your own risk and it works for me.<br />I will say I have developed a routine that for those who breakout like I do after any kind of hair removal has worked with REM Spring. First, don't wash you face with soap before.... just wipe gently with warm water to cleanse and open pores. Use the product area by area. Then on a cotton ball, gently apply some astringent or clarifier to close pores (will sting a bit). The, I take Neosporin spray (not creme or gel) and spray the area cleared. This disinfects the pores and I have had very few pimples from the process.

  1072. I LOVE my R.E.M. spring. I read a lot of the reviews and was nervous about how the pain people complained about but once I tried it, it was no big deal. It doesn't hurt anymore then threading or waxing. I could see how some might not reap the benefits of it because if you can't handle pain at all then trying to make yourself twist the spring could be mentally difficult. I have had the product for about a month and use it maybe once a week (I must have slow hair growth?). I used it a lot when I first got it because I had a lot of &#34;cleaning up&#34; to do but after that initial week I'm down to once a week. There is minimal redness! Honestly, most the time I use it without any redness. When redness does occur, it only last for about 30 minutes. I told my mom and sister about it and they both purchased one and love it as much as I do. My sister was looking for a more cost effective hair removal method since she just graduated college and wants to conserve her cash. My only concern (and this is for the future) is that in order to clean it properly you are supposed to gently pull the spring apart to separate the coils. Then you blow on it to clear out any hair. I think when excessive cleaning the spring might stretch and not be as effective in pulling hair out. I guess I will have to see as time passes. Even if that is the case, this product is so affordable it wouldn't be a big deal to buy a new one every year/ two years/ whatever it ends up being. Great Product!!! Love it! Wouldn't want to live without it!

  1076. Whoever invented this thing is a genius!<br /><br />It takes a few minutes to learn to use it effectively ... and I do recommend one reviewer's suggestion to place your hands closer together than indicated by the handles. Works best for me when there's only about two (maybe 3) inches of spring between my hands. And some areas you need to go over several times from different angles ... like around corners of mouth. It does help to push your tongue out underneath this area to make the skin taut. Yes, it pulls a bit, but, after all, you ARE pulling your hair out; you'd have to have nerve damage not to feel it. But if you're working on a sensitive area, you have the control to go bit by bit and not rip it all out at once. I use it about once a week over most of my face for about an hour while watching TV. You kind of get into a zone with it and you stop noticing the pulling.<br /><br />Anyway, I'll never use cream hair remover on my face again.

  1105. I was afraid that it wouldn't work. I was pleasantly surprised. I sought this out because razors leave stubble, epilators are expensive, I don't want strange hair removing chemicals on my face and my skin is too tan to bleach the hair.<br /><br />I tried it out while watching a movie. By the time the movie was over 99% of the hair above my lip was gone. It definitely takes practice though. I had to pause the movie and check my face out in the mirror for a bit. It's great that this gadget can remove tiny and fine hairs! I just held it in the u-shape, twisted it and moved it up and down over the area. Make certain that the hair is pulled out and not simply tugged on by twisting in full movements rather than short and rapid movements. All in all this product is fantastic! This is so much better than shaving my face and getting razor cuts.<br /><br /> I use it everywhere on my face, because I'm pretty hairy. I use it on my chin, upper lip, cheeks and neck area. It is good at getting the fine hairs- I save the more wiry hairs for the tweezers. This is quicker than tweezers, but also pulling out multiple hairs makes the pain more tolerable. Keep it mind that sometimes it does not get every single hair- so use a razor or a pair of tweezers afterwards if you miss any. This is not the one tool for every single hair, but it's definitely worth owning and using regularly.<br /><br />It does not hurt- the pain is not even as bad as a pin prick. It's a small price to pay for removing the hair. If the pain bothers you- try a pain reliever. I took two ibuprofen before doing my entire face.
  1106. this really works. after all these years of tweezing, bleaching, scissoring, etc. i had my doubts. after reading all the reviews decided it was worth the try. if u can put up with the stinging, u will love it.
  1107. I got this today off Amazon after a fruitless local search for a threading tool. This had such good ratings, I decided to buy it.<br /><br />I am so impressed!!<br /><br />Yes, it does hurt. Is it horrible? Nah. The only *really* sensitive area is right above the lip. Other areas I was able to continue to use it without taking a break for a breather.<br /><br />I have very fine blonde hair on my face, but it gets a tad too long for my liking. Waxing and epilation there has proven to be a disaster for breakouts. I used this last night, and my face barely looked red even five minutes after.<br /><br />It takes a little bit to get the trick down to use it, but it was very easy to use. I'm excited to continue using this cost effective hair removal solution.
  1108. I have been using different methods to remove some minor facial hair (you know the long occassional hair that wants to surface once you are over 40 :) mostly tweezing and i used facial removal creme for some fluffy hairs before.<br />the product will definitely work, even as I see it very time consuming, but my biggest problem is that if your hair is as short as mine, as I maintain the growth every week, the hairs seemed way to short to be grabbed by the remover. It left to many hairs that were just slightly coming through the skin and if you came really really close to my face you would have noticed them even as i am light skinned and the hair grows in very light.<br /><br />Think I maybe will try it a few more times to make sure my technique is good, but I think my main issue will be that it is very time consuming. Oh and yes it does hurt, am sure with continued use as some stated you will get more used to that part.<br /><br />overall , for the price maybe worth a try to see if it works for you

  1113. This will pull out *some* unwanted hairs, but skips right over others even after repeated attempts to remove them. But the reason I'm giving the product so few stars isn't only due to that. I think the spring is treated with something (perhaps an oil of some sort?) that causes raised bumps on my chin. It's like an odd kind of acne and looks to me like an allergic reaction. Most unpleasant. (These bumps aren't from pinching; I didn't experience the pain that others have mentioned. Also, the spots didn't show up immediately. There was a delay between using the spring and the bumps starting to emerge.) I would warn anyone with sensitive skin and/or allergies to look for another hair-removal product. I tossed it in the trash.<br /><br />Update: I took some Benedryl for a couple days and that got rid of the skin reaction.
  1114. I have to admit that I do not have much facial hair; however, I am a girl and I want to get rid of any hair on the upper lip area. So I bought this and it works like a charm. It tears me up as it removes the hair, but soon you get used to the pain for you to finish rest of the procedure. I usually do this (once every 2 weeks) after I wash my face at night (to remove any bacteria off my face first). After removing the hair, I lightly rinse out the upper lip with warm water and pat it dry. Then I place a thin layer of aloe vera gel on the upper lip to calm down the skin and prevent possible infection.
  1115. I love it. its cheap but does the job. At first, it's kinda tricky to use but you will learn how to use it after a while. Now you don't need to buy an expensive epilator, or electronic hair remover. I totally recommend this product.<br />But note that this is good for facial hair only.

  1117. Who knew that this little strange looking tool would actually work! But, I'm so glad I purchased it. You kind of have to get the hang of it, but once you do, it works great. I wish I would have found this 20 years ago. All the great reviews on Amazon always help me in my decision when purchasing anything. Thanks.
  1118. This product is a keeper!! I have tried several products to eliminate embarrassing facial hair and I finally found what I have been looking for. Who knew - just a simple spring!! Don't be afraid of reviews about the pain - yes, it is a little uncomfortable in certain areas, but trust me it is NOT PAINFUL! But most of all, IT WORKS!!As far as tips for technique... what worked best for me was to slightly bend the spring, place it below where I want to begin hair removal and then twist the ends back and forth as I slowly moved it up my skin. Some have stated to move the ends counter-clockwise of each other - if that works for you, great, but this is what I found is easiest and best results for me. Also, for those tight places, such as the sides of the face against the ear... I found that still bending the spring but putting one side of the spring against where you want the hair removed worked the best. Even the side of the spring will remove the hair. As far as cleaning or getting those hairs out of the spring - I found that if I held on to both ends and quickly pulled the spring apart and snapped it back together quickly removed the hair - in addition, pull the spring apart and blow on it very hard. That's all it took! If you have facial hair you want to get rid of - get this product!!
  1119. This product is really easy to use and is very efficient. I love that it pulls the hair from the roots. Other than hurting a little if you're using it for the first time it's great! I would imagine less pain with frequent use. Also, it looks like it's easy to clean. I love that I don't have to use any chemicals to remove unwanted facial hair!

I had developed a darkening at the mustache area and after researching it found it could be do to irritating hair removal products. It was pretty embarrassing and took about a year to get it to lighten with prescription cream.   1137. I ordered the REM Spring Facial Hair Remover from the seller. The item did not arrive with the velvet pouch that this should come in. I contacted the seller regarding the issue but there is no reply yet on the replacement. I'm assuming that they have sent me a previously returned product because the box opening flaps were worn out like it has been opened before. I did end up with little red bumps all over my face. The product does work as advertised. Do not use on the eyebrows. After using this product, I'm ambivalent about the justification of spending $20 on this. You're going to want to buy some rubbing alcohol so that the spring can be cleaned out after each use. It is painful and it's a time consuming process since the spring wont grab all the hair at once. However the process is much more pleasant than individually plucking the hairs out.
